talk.start.para: —I rise in today's matter of public importance discussion to add my voice to those of people with disabilities, their families and carers about the necessity to tackle the enormous unmet need for services for people with disabilities in this country. This is one of the great social problems confronting Australia and it is imperative that we begin to tackle the needs of people with disabilities in a coordinated, structured and strategic way immediately.

speech.para: The needs of the community of people with disabilities are now well documented. Unfortunately I do not think those needs are well understood, nor have they been taken seriously enough in a political context. The services that people with disabilities require must be part of the political agenda, must be part of the community's agenda and must be part of all our thinking, because it is important that we as a community commit ourselves to meeting the needs of these people.

The consequences of the needs of people with disabilities going unmet are largely unseen by the wider community because the people with disabilities and their carers soldier on, making do in very difficult circumstances. They continue to suffer, often in silence, trying to eke out the best lives they can. But their needs are real and very pressing, and we really must do something as a community to help tackle these needs.

The breadth of the needs of people with disabilities has been well recorded in the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare's report. It says that 13,400 people aged between five and 64 have unmet needs for assistance with self-care, mobility and verbal communication. Another 38,000 require employment services. There are 12,000 people aged 18 to 64 who are not currently receiving day programs under the Commonwealth-State Disability Agreement. An estimated 7,700 people with a severe or profound handicap have principal caregivers who are over 65 years of age, not to mention those with mild disabilities. We have a huge social problem in our community that has now, as I said, been well documented.

But it is the personal stress of those involved that most needs to be understood. I am sure all senators have been receiving correspondence from people with examples of the sorts of problems people experience in providing adequate care for people with disabilities, organising respite care and meeting the daily essential needs of these thousands of Australian citizens.

It is encouraging to note that the state and federal ministers will be meeting on 9 April to discuss some of these issues. It is highly unfortunate that the meeting was not held earlier. The federal minister, Senator Newman, has been under pressure since the last election from the disability groups, and I think some of the state governments, to have a meeting. Unfortunately that meeting has not been scheduled until 9 April this year. The key point about that delay is that consideration of matters for this year's federal budget closed in February. So we have a situation where the disability ministers are not meeting to discuss how we might best tackle this enormous demand for services for people with disabilities until after the federal budget considerations have been decided.

By 9 April it will be too late to have any impact on the shape of the 11 May budget. It will be too late for this year's budget to ensure that sufficient extra funds are provided from the Commonwealth to assist with meeting this great social need. People with disabilities and their support people can rightly be critical of the government for failing to meet with the state ministers earlier and for failing to seriously tackle this issue at an earlier time. I do hope that the minister does attend that meeting with a view to having a serious discussion about how, jointly with the state governments, the Commonwealth government can play its role in addressing this serious, unmet need.

This Commonwealth government does not have a great record in the area of assisting people with disabilities, given that in its first budget around $138 million was cut out of the disability services area. We are still not back to scratch in terms of the contribution of the Commonwealth government. But I do not want to make a highly political contribution today. I want to lend my voice to those people in the community with disabilities, and the people who support and care for them, with regard to the necessity for government to tackle the very real needs that these people have and the services they require.

It has been estimated that those needs could be met with a budget allocation of about $300 million extra. That may sound like a lot of money and of course it is, but it is a question of priorities. In terms of the Commonwealth government, $300 million is not a massive amount of money. We managed recently to spend $1.7 billion on propping up private health insurance in this country, paying people on high incomes a subsidy so that they could take out private health insurance. The government thought that was a priority; I say that we must make the needs of people with disabilities in this country a higher priority. The $300 million that they require to provide essential services so that they can live decent lives and so that their carers can get some respite is not too much to ask.

This government is not helping with its goods and services tax proposal because people with disabilities will be among those who suffer most from this proposition. People with disabilities are huge consumers of services. Things that we sometimes purchase as discretionary services are absolutely essential for people with disabilities. They require taxis and have transportation needs at a much higher level than people without disabilities. They often require a whole range of services in the home, as well as personal care services, to just eke out an existence as close to normal as possible.

A tax on services, as proposed by the government, will very adversely affect this group of people. The compensation measures for them are not specifically targeted, but are merely the average compensation measures determined by the government. So, at the same time as having this huge, unmet need, the new tax on services for people with disabilities will be a further barrier to their full participation in society and their access to the most basic of services.

But my central theme today is the need to meet this huge demand for services for people with disabilities. It is most worrying that the minister's recent comments indicate that she believes this is really a state matter and that states will be getting an awful lot of extra money from GST revenue and, therefore, it is an issue that the states ought to address using those additional revenues if the GST is passed. That is an unacceptable approach. There is no doubt that there are state responsibilities in the area of disability services, but there is a need for a Commonwealth-state partnership to tackle this huge issue of the unmet needs of people with disabilities.

The ministers meeting on 9 April represents a very real opportunity to map out a strategic, long-term approach to meeting those needs. I accept that not all of those needs can be met in the short term. Sure, extra money is needed, and extra money should be provided; but there is also a need for more facilities and other initiatives that require longer term planning and longer term investment. What should come out of the state and Commonwealth ministers meeting is that strategic plan—a commitment to a long-term strategy to tackle the needs of people with disabilities and to provide the funds on an ongoing basis to meet that demand.

People with disabilities do not want just a few scraps from the table—$20 million or $30 million here or there for some pet project. They want a strategic plan to address these very real needs and to tackle the problems confronting people with disabilities in this country. It would be a very real shame if the meeting of state and federal ministers on 9 April failed to deliver that sort of strategic approach.

talk.start.para: —Today I want to bring to the attention of the Senate a project that is trying to boost the bilby population in Queensland. It is a chance for all of those who claim to be friends of the bush, wildlife and conservation to do something positive.

speech.para: The bilby is a small marsupial with grey and tan hair, and a distinctive black and white tail. It produces only one or two young at a time. Bilby populations are currently under threat. Their low birth rate is not the only factor that has contributed to the decline in bilby numbers. Over time, predators such as the red fox, feral cats and the dingo have threatened bilby populations. Competition for food between introduced and native species has led to a decrease in bilby numbers.

Four-fifths of the area previously inhabited by the bilby in Queensland no longer hosts the species. Across Australia, sparse populations are found only in isolated desert areas in Western Australia, the Northern Territory and Queensland. In Queensland, only 600 to 700 bilbies can be found in a 100,000 kilometre radius stretching from Birdsville to Boulia. Previously, this large expanse of Queensland was host to a healthy bilby population.

In response to the declining population, a Queensland group, including Frank Manthey and others, has proposed establishing a bilby breeding program from a colony of 30 bilbies currently in Charleville. The proposal is to increase numbers by housing bilbies in an enclosure designed to keep out predators and to reduce competition from other species. By protecting the small bilby from large, more rapacious animals and ensuring it has adequate food, the proposed project would give a jump-start to the bilby population. Enclosures five kilometres by five kilometres with two-metre high fences and electric wires would provide a formidable deterrent to hungry predators.

Once a healthy population of several hundred bilbies was reached, the animals would be gradually released through small openings in the fence into the immediate area. Hopefully they would then spread through their natural geographical habitat across Currawinya Park, near Hungerford, and even go further. The introduced predators would be subject to a control program before the bilbies were released. It is hoped that these larger populations would be able to fend off competitor species and would actively breed in their natural environment.

The project is in need of financial assistance. Individuals who contribute $20 to the project will be recognised on a plaque on the bilby fence. This is a chance for all of the people with the green credentials to put their money where their mouth is. I will be inviting all senators, particularly the Democrats, to do something positive for the bilby population. I will look forward to seeing whether Senator Woodley has his cheque in the mail. I will certainly be sending mine. The appeal for funds, which was launched this week, will run until the end of the year or until enough donations are received. Larger donations from corporate organisations are graciously welcomed. The entire project is estimated to cost $250,000.

While this project would be practically solving the decline in bilby numbers, it would also have a research component. Under a national recovery plan and a state rescue plan, coordinated research would be conducted into the biology and ecology of the species. Armed with scientific knowledge about the decrease in bilby populations, participants would be able to identify threats to the bilby population and devise new plans to stabilise the species. Stabilisation is vital.

Currently the bilby is listed as vulnerable nationally and endangered in Queensland. With further losses, it is possible that the national listing will also be upgraded to endangered. This is a worthy project but public assistance is needed if Australia is to have a healthy bilby population despite what happens in the wild.

While the Astrebla Downs National Park in the Channel Country has the most significant remaining population, previous unreliable rainfall has made the area unsuitable for the bilby project. Currawinya National Park has been chosen because it was formerly the heart of the Queensland bilby population. It is a large national park with permanent staff who can be dedicated to the task of saving this important marsupial. It is also an area with a diverse and reliable bilby food supply. Let us hope the park can once again play host to a robust bilby population.

Donations of nearly $14,000 have already been received from ordinary Australians and some from larger corporations. As I said, I will be donating to the project myself. This is a chance to do something very positive for wildlife conservation. I will be looking to see how Senator Woodley responds to this, and Senator Brown too.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I inform the Senate that Senator Vanstone is absent today. She is visiting Asia, Europe and America for consultations with ministerial counterparts and law enforcement and drug experts on operational aspects of her portfolio. During her absence, Senator Ellison will take questions relating to the Justice and Customs portfolio, the Attorney-General's portfolio and the Immigration and Cultural Affairs portfolio.

—My question is to Senator Hill in his capacity as Minister representing the Minister for Trade. Can the minister inform the Senate precisely what contribution the following government measures have made to Australia's disastrous second successive record monthly trade deficit: the government's $359 million budget cuts to our trade programs; the government's 30 per cent cut to the Austrade budget over the last three years compared with the previous three years; and the government's 25 per cent cut to the Export Market Development Grants Scheme?

—The trade figures reflect the fact that we have such a strong domestic economy with the background of basically a weak external situation. To some extent, therefore, our trade figures are not as good as we might like, because of the fact that we have done so well as a government and have put in place the conditions under which the Australian economy is booming in the way it is now. It was interesting last night to hear the deputy editor of the Economist referring to the miracle economy of Australia and saying how extraordinary it is with the background of the very weak circumstances existing in Asia at the moment.

answer.para: Of course, it is not a miracle at all; it has occurred through sound economic management, taking hard but difficult decisions that have enabled expenditure to be significantly cut, interest rates to be reduced to their lowest level in 30 years, inflation to be at a record low level, and jobs to be increased in this country. That is the circumstance that has led to a very powerful domestic economy with growth of over four per cent; and that is tending to suck in exports, not surprisingly, whilst at the same time our export markets are weak because of the weakness of our partner economies. That is particularly reflected in relation to figures for commodities at the moment. They are the facts of the matter.

What is comforting is that, because of its strong domestic economy, Australia can withstand difficult external accounts much better than it was able to under Labor. I guess that is just another reason why this government should be applauded for taking those hard decisions, most of which were opposed by the Labor Party.

talk.start.para: —Of course, the structural strength of the economy is due to the reforms made during the Labor government, and the problem with the current account deficit is that we are not exporting enough. Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, won't you acknowledge that the government's ill-conceived and short-sighted cuts to these trade programs have at the very least contributed to making a difficult trade situation worse? Won't you acknowledge that fact? Can you guarantee that the government will rectify those cuts to our export incentive programs in the coming budget?

—I will not concede that; but what I do say is that the answer for the future is to strengthen the domestic economy even further—and the way to do that is with further reform and, in particular, taxation reform. We have been able to reform our expenditure and industrial relations, but what we badly need is to complement that with taxation reform, to introduce an efficient, contemporary taxation system that encourages exports. And what system will encourage exports more than one which has a GST but has no GST on exports? If you are seriously interested in the external accounts, Senator Cook, you should support the government—

answer.para: Senator Cook interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order, Senator Hill. Senator Cook, it is your question and your supplementary question, and you have been interjecting persistently throughout. There is an appropriate time to debate this matter and it is after question time.

—If the Labor Party were serious about external accounts, the first thing they would do would be to support the coalition government in passing tax reform. The opportunity is before the Senate at the moment. The test is in the hands of the Labor Party. Come on board and at last be relevant. This is a chance for Labor to be relevant—just one chance. (Time expired)

—My question is to the Assistant Treasurer, Senator Kemp. Minister, the government's taxation reform package unveiled last year outlines many benefits for average Australian families, including massive income tax relief and increases in family assistance. Would the Assistant Treasurer outline the three major components of the family package in the tax reform proposal, and can he outline how this proposal will benefit average families in my home state of South Australia? Furthermore, could the Assistant Treasurer outline what threats there are to this family tax relief?

—Thank you, Senator, for your question and for the genuine concern you show for Australian families and, in particular, families in South Australia. Senator Ferguson has always had a particular emphasis in his remarks on family policies, so in that sense the question does not surprise me. It is true that families will be big winners from the tax reform package. Today the legislation will be introduced into the parliament to build on the family tax initiative introduced by the government in 1997.

answer.para: Of the three major components of the family package, the first provides a large increase in assistance for most Australian families. Overall, the package is worth in the order of $2.5 billion. The government will firstly provide new family tax benefits, the equivalent of doubling the extra $1,000 tax free threshold for each dependent child under the FTI, thus providing a 70 per cent increase in assistance.

The second measure provides for the equivalent of doubling the extra $2,500 tax free threshold for one-income families with a child aged under five. This is equivalent to not having to pay tax on the first $15,000 of income. Further, we are increasing the maximum assistance for child care for lower income families by $7.50 a week, or some seven per cent.

Another component in our families package provides a substantial boost for assistance for low to middle income families, where there are tax poverty traps—I think that is well known as a problem with the current tax system—through increasing the level of income at which family allowance begins to be income tested from $24,350 to $28,200 a year and reducing the income test withdrawal rate from 50 per cent to 30 per cent. Combined with the large personal income tax cuts, as promised by this government, this greatly increases the rewards available to low and middle income working families.
Honourable senators interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Order! There is conversation going on across the chamber which is in breach of the standing orders and disruptive.

—The third component of the families package is a simplified administrative system of family assistance. The existing complex family assistance system, involving some 12 forms of assistance, will be simplified by reducing the number to just three.

answer.para: The question also asked me about the major threats to this very important package. Of course the major threat comes from the Labor Party's `oppose for the sake of opposing' attitude. We want to deliver major income tax cuts; we want to deliver a major family package; and, frankly, the Labor Party wants to scuttle it.

I mentioned the other day in the Senate how Mr Neil O'Keefe, the member for Burke, had recently written an article in the Melbourne Age saying, `What you vote for is what you get.' We think that is fair enough. Today I would like to draw the Senate's attention to another comment by a Labor member of parliament. This is what a senator, a Labor frontbencher, said earlier this year—and I thought it made sense:
If you don't like the government, what it's doing, you vote it out at the next election. But once you vote them in, you give them a chance to carry out that mandate.
That Labor frontbencher was Senator Chris Schacht. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Assistant Treasurer. In relation to the minister's recent press release which stated `credit in relation to any advance previously paid will be applied to the 1997-98 assessments as provided for by the legislation', I ask: how will people who do not have a superannuation surcharge tax assessment issued in 1997-98 recover advance instalments they have made in the previous year?

—I thank Senator Hogg for that question on the very popular measure that the government announced recently—the abolition of the advance payment. This was a measure which received very strong community support. In particular, we received very strong support from the industry—
—You were humiliated.

—If that is the case, can we have more such occasions? In the superannuation area we received very strong support from all the major industry groups. I think that at the time—I may be wrong; if I am, the Labor senator can correct me—the Labor Party did not even bother to put out a press statement attacking it. There was no press statement, I believe, from the shadow minister. So I assume that this, again, was a measure which was widely welcomed by the Labor Party. It is an extremely important measure. It was supported by ASFA, IFSA and the Australian Institute of Actuaries. We are very pleased and comfortable with those changes. We have strongly welcomed the community support.

—On a point of order, Madam President, I draw your attention to the fact that Senator Kemp was asked whether people who do not have a surcharge tax assessment issued in 1997-98 recover advance instalments they have made in the previous year—I think those were the words that Senator Hogg used. I do think it would be reasonable in this circumstance, given that we have had a couple of minutes of waffle, as usual, from Senator Kemp, to draw his attention to the actual question that was asked and perhaps invite him to break his duck and try to answer the question.
—I think the minister is giving background preamble, but I am sure he is coming to the answer.

—And, I might say, an extremely important background preamble, Madam President. In line with the government's announcement, assessments for the 1997-98 income year, to be issued around 15 May, will not include an advance instalment. Any payments of advance instalment already made will be credited, including against assessments to be issued from May. With regard to 1996-97 assessments, the majority of superannuation funds have complied with the law and paid their surcharge liability.

—I ask a supplementary question, Madam President. Isn't it the case that someone whose 1997-98 income has fallen below the surcharge threshold will not receive an assessment for that year? Isn't it the case that those who received an assessment in 1996-97 but have since died will not be issued with an assessment in 1997-98? Isn't it also the case that women who have left the work force—for instance, to have a baby—will also not be issued with an assessment in 1997-98? How will they receive their advance instalment credit?

—Madam President, where there is a small sort of charge on the advance payment, as I said, if a credit is required, a credit will be given. Where an advance payment has been made and no surcharge is required to be paid the following year, quite clearly the money will be refunded.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Communications, Information Technology and the Arts, Senator Alston. The government is committed to jobs growth, in particular for people living in rural and regional Australia. Will the minister inform the Senate of the positive impact that call centres are having in providing jobs growth in regional Australia, and what is the government doing to assist the regions in attracting new call centres? Is the minister aware of any alternative policy proposals and what would be the impact should these be implemented?

talker.name: Alston, Sen Richard
Senator ALSTON
talker.role: Communications, Information Technology and the Arts

talk.start.para: —Call centres are a rapidly expanding industry. There are a number of international firms flocking to Australia to take advantage of a number of very important comparative advantages that we have. It is quite clear that we have not only a multilingual work force but we also have very skilled workers, we have very advanced telecommunications infrastructure and we have a unique time zone position. All of these factors come together to make Aus tralia a very attractive location for call centres. Regional communities in particular are an attractive location, as Senator Watson would appreciate, because companies looking to set up call centres are usually looking for locations where there is low staff turnover and low cost structures, where the quality of life is very attractive and where people tend to have a more customer friendly focus.

answer.para: In Tasmania in particular that has been the experience to date. That is why some 2,600 jobs have already been created in call centres in that state alone. It is very encouraging indeed that firms such as Ansett, Qantas, Westpac, Centrelink, the Taxation Office, Watts Communications and other telecommunications carriers are identifying Tasmania as a very important opportunity for them—something like $170 million worth of business for the Tasmanian economy. The number of call centres is growing at the rate of about 20 per cent a year throughout Australia. It is an industry worth close to $2½ billion, and that should continue.

It certainly will continue while we are in government because we are very keen to encourage people to move into sunrise industries. People should be aware of the fact that the starting salary for a graduate in a call centre is approximately $32,000, with some managers earning in excess of $300,000. More than 50 per cent of call centre employees are tertiary graduates and more than half are under 30. It ought to be patently clear that this is one of the big employment opportunities of the future. So we ask ourselves: why is it that the Labor Party constantly denigrates this form of employment? The answer is: because there are not too many union members employed in call centres. The ACTU even had the gall to denigrate call centres on the Business program recently, calling them `sweat shops'.

Here we have a perfect opportunity for an expanding industry in places like Tasmania which desperately need encouragement for this sort of activity, and you lot are bagging them. Is it any wonder that John Della Bosca has to come to Canberra to tell Kim Beazley that the voters are sick of Labor's negativity?

talk.start.para: —Mr Beazley, Senator.

—Mr Beazley, Madam President. Wake up to yourselves. Of course they are. They want you to get out there and barrack for middle Australia. They do not want you simply to be playing for those who have put you in this place so that you can have a nice, cosy little time and ignore the interests of mainstream Australia. How humiliating! How demeaning that a state secretary, some dishevelled genius, as Mr Carr calls him—he is probably half right—has to come to Canberra to tell the federal Leader of the Opposition where he has it horribly wrong. He says, `There are big lessons in New South Wales for you. One of the major lessons is: wake up and start listening to middle Australia.' Middle Australia want jobs for themselves and for their children. They want these employment opportunities. Stop bagging them and encourage them. (Time expired)

—My question is to Senator Herron, representing the Minister for Aged Care. I ask the minister: can he confirm that the Productivity Commission's report on nursing home subsidies released today rejects the government's coalescence proposal for nursing home funding? Does the minister now concede that the Productivity Commission is right and that the government's proposal would lead to a significant reduction in the quality of care for older Australians in a number of states? Will the minister finally rule out the introduction of this central plank of the government's aged care reforms?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator West for the question. Yes, I am aware of the Productivity Commission's report, which we are quite happy to respond to. The Treasurer asked the independent Productivity Commission to investigate relative costs of residential aged care between states and the likely future distribution of government funding. The Productivity Commission delivered its final report to the Treasurer on 13 January this year. The report, as Senator West mentioned, was released yesterday, and the point that the government would like to make in relation to the Productivity Commission's report is that the government has already categorically ruled out any changes to resident fees and charges as a result of the report. It raises a number of issues that the government will consult on and make a decision about in coming months. So there are a number of issues.

answer.para: The report supports the government's objective of a funding structure based on a standard rate across Australia with supplements for higher cost rural and remote areas. Let us remember that the state-by-state funding structure now in place is Labor's system. The current system is a legacy of Labor's mismanagement. It is the system that gave Queensland providers the lowest subsidy of all states. The coalition has been left with the responsibility to fix it. The Labor Party entrenched a funding system that locked in out-of-date cost differences between the states. We, on the other hand, looked at the evidence and, accordingly, decided to move towards a national subsidy. The report vindicates this decision.

The government is moving to uniform national subsidies by a mechanism called coalescence. The issue of coalescence is not about residents' fees but about how $3 billion in taxpayers' funding is distributed to 3,000 residential care facilities across Australia to care for 135,000 Australians in need of care. The government currently provides additional funding for the special needs of service providers in rural and remote areas. It will ensure the structures are designed for fair distribution of funding to provide the residential care that is needed by a small, but extremely important, minority of older Australians.

Our focus is on individuals and their need for quality care. Providers are the means of delivering that care. Nursing homes are receiving substantially more income under the coalition reforms than they ever did under Labor. In 1997-98 the Howard government spent over $3.6 billion on aged and community care. The outlay in 1998-99 is budgeted to grow strongly by 4.2 per cent to $3.8 billion. In 1995-96 the Labor government, under Finance Minister Kim Beazley, spent only $2.4 billion on residential aged care alone. The outlay of the coalition government in 1998-99 is budgeted to be $2.9 billion.

Not surprisingly, the report found that there was no evidence of a funding crisis in the industry. You will recall, Madam President, the bleating that went on before the last election. The report states:

The substantial prices paid for bed licences do not sit comfortably with the view that there is a funding crisis in the sector. Similarly, the Commission notes that many homes, private for-profit and not-for-profit alike, are producing operating surpluses under current subsidy levels, even in the lowest subsidy state of Queensland.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister has failed to answer what the government's proposals are in relation to coalescence. Will the government pursue this central plank of their act to introduce coalescence or does the minister agree that the Productivity Commission's report confirmed that coalescence—like accommodation bonds—was another ill-conceived element of the government's aged care package?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —For the benefit of senators, coalescence is the move towards a uniform or standard funding regime for subsidies paid by the government to nursing home owners.
—We know what it is.

—They do not want to hear it, they are not interested—not only do they have no knowledge of it whatsoever but also they are not interested. They do not care about older Australians. I think they could at least listen to the report.

answer.para: Prior to the implementation of the Aged Care Act 1997, recurrent subsidies for hostels and the infrastructure component of funding for nursing homes were paid on the basis of uniform national rates, while subsidies for nursing and personal care in nursing homes were paid on state specific rates. The government decided on coalescence because it brings funding into line with relative costs and will make the aged care funding system simpler, more effective and better in the longer term. There will be no fee increases. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the proposal by the British government through BNFL and Pangea to build an international nuclear dump in Australia and I ask: is it correct that the British Prime Minister's chief numbers man, Mr Philip Gould, met with Pangea and BNFL and has a specific brief to manage the nuclear dump through any Australian resistance? If this is the case, what is the minister going to do about it? Will the minister write to Tony Blair and tell him unequivocally that not now, not ever, will any Australian government allow the importation of another country's nuclear waste?

—This could be a dorothy dixer because it gives me the opportunity to state again that this government does not have a policy of accepting the nuclear waste of other countries. It is not a business that we intend to get into. We have said on many occasions that it is not in our interest. What the role of Mr Blair's chief numbers man is in relation to the matter is of little interest to me.
—Madam President, I raise a point of order. I asked the minister a specific question and I wonder if you could direct him to answer that question.
—There is no point of order.
—I said no. I also said I was not particularly interested in the attitude or views of Mr Blair's chief numbers man in relation to the matter.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. The minister did not answer my question, which was whether or not the government would write to Tony Blair. I further ask: is the minister aware that the Australian High Commission in London asked for information on the Pangea project from the British government? Did the commissioner do this under instructions from the minister? What was the nature of the request for information? Will the minister give an undertaking to table in the Senate all of the information received by the government and all departments and agencies on the Pangea proposal?
—I have no intention of writing to Mr Blair regarding the matter. I do not know of the communications to which the honourable senator is referring. I do not see any reason to table any documents.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged Care. Is the minister aware of the practice of nursing homes downgrading their nursing staff positions to aged care workers? Does the minister agree that this is nothing more than a cost cutting measure which will both reduce conditions of employment for nurses and undermine the standards of care in nursing homes? Will the minister undertake to investigate the prevalence of this practice and take steps to prevent it?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Gibbs for the question. The practices in the nursing homes at present have evolved over many years. There are standards that have developed under the previous government and under the Howard-Fischer government. They have been reviewed from time to time by the industry itself and that process is a continuous one. The decision is frequently made by particular nursing homes, both for-profit and not-for-profit, in relation to their own facilities. It is dependent on the decision of the proprietors, but under the supervision of the government at the time. If Senator Gibbs has a specific matter that she wishes to refer to, I would be happy to refer it to the minister and have it examined.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Thank you, Minister. I do have a specific matter in mind, but it is my information that this is happening throughout Australia, in particular since the Aged Care Bill came about. I ask you again: will you undertake to ask the Minister for Aged Care to investigate the prevalence of this practice and take steps to prevent it?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I do not believe that it is a common practice throughout Australia. Senator Gibbs has made this out.
—How would you know?
—I would ask how Senator Carr knows. It will not be long before he is in a nursing home at the rate he is going, given the factional problems in Victoria.
—Madam Speaker, I raise a point of order. It is becoming a habit of the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs to sling off at people.
—Ha, ha!

—And now he is slinging off at people in nursing homes. This might be amusing to the Liberal Party, but I am sure there are a lot of people listening who would not approve of that sort of approach from the minister who represents the portfolio of Aged Care in this chamber. I would ask you to rule on the point of order.
—There is no point of order.
—Madam President—
—There is no point of order.

—I raise a separate point of order, and it is this: if Senator Faulkner is to be allowed to get up and behave in the way that he just has, which deserves, I would have thought, the century's award for sanctimoniousness, he should be prepared to undertake to behave in the manner that he expects others to behave. Madam President, all you ever get is sledging across the chamber, he turns his back on you whenever you speak to him, he treats you with total contempt and ignores your rulings. You should not entertain any more submissions from him unless he is prepared to undertake to set a better example.
—There is no point of order. We will proceed with question time. All senators are aware of the provisions of standing order 203 and I should not have to remind them of it.

—I dispute the fact that this is across Australia. The Aged Care Act requires that providers maintain an adequate number of appropriately skilled staff to ensure that the care needs of residents are met.
—Why do you hate old people?
—Senator Faulkner, you have been interjecting persistently throughout question time. I remind you of the provisions of standing order 203.

—The act also sets out accreditation procedures, which must be followed and which require providers to have in place a skills mix appropriate to the care needs of the residents and arrangements for the ongoing development of staff skills. The act requires it, we fulfil the act and I do not believe the proposition that Senator Gibbs has put forward. But, as I say, if she has a specific incident that she is referring to, I would be happy to follow it up.

—My question is to the Minister representing the Minister for Foreign Affairs. I refer to the murderous events in Kosovo under the Milosevic regime. Minister, what direct response has the Australian government made to the call by former Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser to ensure that NATO does not hit civilians and in particular refugee camps in Serbia? Has a direct approach been made to NATO about that? Given the chilling rumours that people are being herded into sports stadia in Pristina and other almost unthinkable barbarities flowing from such events occurring in Kosovo, what is the government's view about the use of land operations in Kosovo by NATO?
—It is unnecessary for this government to advise NATO that it should take care to avoid hitting civilian targets. Obviously NATO is taking every care possible to that end.
—They aren't doing a good job, are they?

—I think the NATO parties are doing an excellent job in all the circumstances, Senator Carr. NATO is fighting oppression; it is fighting an appalling situation brought about by President Milosevic and his regime. We should be giving those who are putting their lives at risk to save others credit rather than attacking them. I am disappointed to hear your attitude to this matter. I hope it does not reflect that of the Australian Labor Party as a whole.

answer.para: The circumstances are, as I said, appalling. The estimates a couple of days ago were that there were half a million displaced ethnic Albanians—many tens of thousands per day, unfortunately—as a result of the actions of President Milosevic and his regime, for which he must accept total responsibility. It need not go on. There is no need for it to go on. All that is necessary is for President Milosevic to recognise that he should adhere to internationally accepted human rights standards in relation to all of the people of Yugoslavia, withdraw his forces from Kosovo and cease the barbaric acts that he is inflicting upon ethnic Albanians in Kosovo and the matters will come to an end and there will not be a continuation of the human suffering that we are experiencing.

The position of the Australian government has been to support the action that has been taken by NATO parties. Where we can be of assistance in relation to the humanitarian crisis we will do so, but we have no direct part in the military action that is taking place and we do not intend to tell NATO how they should do their business.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question, and I must record my disagreement. I think the federal government does have a role in levying humanitarian pressure on both sides. I ask the minister: what direct aid is the Australian government considering giving to the countries surrounding Kosovo: Albania, Macedonia and in particular Montenegro, which is now faced with an awesome humanitarian crisis from the flow of refugees? Is the Australian government considering—and has it brought to the front burner—an Australian plan to take part in what is going to be an international effort if this is not going to turn into a human tragedy outside Kosovo as well as inside Kosovo?

—I did not say that there was not a role that we could play in relation to the humanitarian aspects of this conflict. In fact, as Mr Downer has said, we are exploring as a matter of urgency ways in which we can assist those who are suffering. We are doing it through intergovernmental contact and also through existing aid agencies. The highest priorities are of course the medical and shelter needs of refugees, and we are looking at ways in which we can offer humanitarian assistance in that regard. That is a role that we can play, although obviously it is relatively modest as we are so far away. The other thing I said which seemed to be misinterpreted by Senator Brown is that we do not have a direct role in the military action that is taking place in Kosovo and the former Yugoslavia.

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of the distinguished former Victorian senator, Mr John Button. I welcome you to the Senate. We are very pleased to see you.
—Hear, hear!

—My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. I refer to the minister's answer yesterday to a question about the impact of the GST on indigenous communities, in which he said:

question.para: While some food items might increase, many in fact will be cheaper because we will abolish Labor's hidden tax—the wholesale sales tax—
For the benefit of indigenous communities, could the minister name the many foods which will be cheaper?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —All those that are taxed now.
—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Isn't it a fact that the only food items that attract a WST are fruit and vegetable juices?
—Wrong!
—Order! Senators should appreciate that Senator Herron needs to hear the question.

—Isn't it also a fact that these items attract only a 12 per cent sales tax applied to the wholesale price, as opposed to the government's GST, which will see a 10 per cent tax applied to the retail price, thus making these items more expensive under the GST than they would be under the existing tax system?

—The supplementary question is based on totally false premises, and I would ask Senator Conroy: when have you been to an Aboriginal community? I will guarantee you that there is no record of Senator Conroy ever having been to an Aboriginal community, either remote, rural or anywhere, and I reject the statements made in his supplementary question.

subdebateinfo.title: Tax Reform: Mining and Manufacturing Sectors

talk.start.para: —My question is for the Minister for Industry, Science and Resources, Senator Minchin. The coalition went to the last election with a detailed policy of tax reform to replace the ramshackle and ambiguous system we have had since the 1930s. I ask the minister: what are the benefits for the resources and manufacturing industries of this overdue and very much needed tax reform?

—As Senator Lightfoot knows only too well, mining and manufacturing are vital to Australia's economic wellbeing. Together they generate around half our export income, which Senator Cook seems to be concerned about, and they employ over a million Australians. It is a national imperative that we ensure that these industries can compete successfully internationally and that we remove all impediments to that competitiveness.

answer.para: One of the biggest impediments these industries face is our current tax system. This is of course what our irrelevant opposition wants us to keep. The current wholesale sales tax is one of the most pernicious taxes on manufacturing imaginable. A well-known Australian, in advocating that we do replace the wholesale sales tax with a GST, said:
. . . it will allow a more rational indirect tax system than the current anomaly-ridden wholesale sales tax, which has multiple rates, numerous exemptions, and fails to tax the services sector.
That of course was none other than the latest star of 60 Minutes , Paul Keating, in 1985. There are any number of examples of what Paul Keating was talking about.

We had the discussion of food. We had the problem with yoghurt and whether or not it should be taxed under this system, and that had to go to the Federal Court. Ice-cream is taxed—that is a food and it is taxed—but frozen yoghurt is exempt. So we had the problem of what to do about a form of yoghurt that is delivered to retailers frozen but sold as soft-serve. The Administrative Appeals Tribunal said it was not yoghurt and therefore it was not exempt. It had to go to the Federal Court, who said the AAT were wrong.

Something as simple as a chair is taxed at two different rates—12 per cent if it is for household purposes and 22 per cent if it is for office purposes, and they have enormous difficulty working out which is which.

The wholesale sales tax system, which Labor wants us to keep, taxes household essentials like washing machines and fridges but, if you want to go to the opera, that is tax free. Toothpaste is taxed, but the brush that you put it on, under Labor's tax system, is not. This is an insane tax system for a modern economy.

What did Labor do in the lead-up to the last election? What was their plan? How did they approach what Paul Keating had said 14 years ago were the problems with the current tax system? After 2½ years of labouring away about what to do with the current tax system, what did they come up with? A grand plan to take the WST off orange juice and stick it on caviar and Lear jets. That was the product of 2½ years of intensive policy work to reform our tax system. What a joke! We recognised that we had to fix the tax system. We went to the people asking for a mandate, which they gave us, to remove your wholesale sales tax. Our plan gets rid of that plus nine other taxes which burden Australian industry.

We are going to take 4.4 per cent off the cost of mining in this country. Chris Murphy, in a report to the Senate inquiry into this issue, said that mining production would be boosted by seven per cent—employment in mining will rise by 7,000 people. Even dear Senator Cook recognises the advantages to mining. He said to the mining industry in the Senate inquiry:
There is a quantifiable—subject to advice of course—advantage to your industry, I suspect, from the ANTS package.

Senator Cook recognises that this package will be good for the mining industry—one of the most important industries in his state—but he is going to vote against it. As Senator Alston has said, why don't you take advice from the two best professionals you have ever had—Bob Hogg and John Della Bosca—get out of the mud, get out of the trap you are in and pass the package?

talk.start.para: —My question is to Senator Herron, the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs. Will the minister join with civic leaders in Victoria in condemning Mr Sam Newman's tasteless, humourless and offensive parody of an Aboriginal footballer which was based on crude racial stereotypes? Or does he regard this as merely another Haase type joke?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I thank Senator Schacht for the question. I note that the AFL have already taken action in relation to Mr Newman's parody of Nicky Winmar on The Footy Show . This includes the counselling of players on issues of racism, which counselling I and the government totally support—we are totally against racism of any kind. But, more specifically, the parties involved have been brought together and I understand a resolution has been reached—that was on the media today—and the steps undertaken by the AFL have been most appropriate. In light of this, I do not believe that anything further can be achieved other than what has already been achieved by the AFL and by the people concerned.

—Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. Minister, you say that you congratulate the AFL for the work it has done—and so do we—in taking initiatives to remove racism from within their sport, which is certainly admirable, but I note in your answer that you did not say you disagreed with what Mr Newman said, but that you agreed with the process of the AFL. I ask you, Minister: do you agree with Mr Newman's tasteless, humourless and offensive parody?

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I think the issue is resolved. I can disagree or agree, as the case may be, but the issue has been resolved. Senator Schacht trying to keep the issue going achieves nothing; it stirs up racism. I do not really believe there is any virtue in keeping the issue going, because if you keep the issue going—as Senator Schacht is trying to do—then it achieves something which I think both sides of the chamber do not wish to support. I have already stated my position.

answer.para: Senator Conroy interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Senator Conroy, I invite you to note the provisions of the standing orders.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. I do note in today's question time that when, according to you, an opposition senator has interjected, you have used their name in calling them to order, but when government senators have interjected, you have given a general warning to senators, which I think is both unfair and inappropriate. This is a serious point of order about the way you are calling senators to order, and I am concerned that it is partisan. I ask you in this circumstance to review the tape of this question time and take account of the serious point of order I am making to you.
—There is a difference between a number of senators making a noise—as sometimes happens on both sides of the chamber—and individuals shouting persistently, and I take notice of that.

—Madam President, I rise on a further point of order. There is a difference, as you have indicated, but I am drawing attention to what I believe is a different practice on your part. I am concerned that it is partisan, and I ask in this circumstance that you review what has occurred in this question time. My concern is that when a government senator is interjecting there is a general warning to senators, but you are calling opposition senators to order by name, whether that be appropriate or inappropriate. That is the matter I am raising with you, and I ask you to review it.
—I reject your suggestion. I will review it—I frequently review question time, and I wish others would do likewise.

—Madam President, I rise on a point of order. When you review the tape, I wonder if it will feature how often Senator Faulkner constantly flouts your rulings. You have called Senator Faulkner to order many times, and it has no apparent effect on him. Virtually every minister that stands up here and answers a question is subjected to constant abuse from Senator Faulkner. In the context of reviewing the tape, I think it is very important to look at the behaviour of Senator Faulkner, which I think in this chamber is absolutely disgraceful.
—There is no point of order, and the Senate should proceed with question time.

—Madam President, on a further point of order. Under the guise of points of order, we have already had in this question time today a spurious point made by Senator Alston and now a spurious point made by Senator Kemp. That is an abuse of the standing orders of this Senate. It is an abuse of question time. While you consider the other matter, in relation to the behaviour of government senators during question time, I ask you to give that some consideration.

subdebateinfo.title: Goods and Services Tax: State Housing Authorities

talk.start.para: —My question is to the Minister for Family and Community Services. Does the minister agree that the proposed tax changes as they currently stand will lead to an increase in costs for state housing authorities of, at the very minimum, at least five per cent? The minister would be aware that the current round of funding under the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement expires at the end of June. Why is the government not willing to consider providing adequate, or indeed any, extra funding to state housing authorities in the new agreement to cover the inevitable cost rises that will occur with the GST? Or does the minister agree with the statement made to the Senate Community Affairs Committee by the executive director of her department, Mr Tune, that the cost impact of the GST on public and community housing is just `the states' problem'?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —An issue which is obviously of interest to all of us is how public housing will fare into the future. One of the important things to remember is that the state governments provide a range of services, some of which, under the new tax proposals, will in fact mean a substantial reduction in their costs. In terms of public housing, there will be a small increase. I am not sure whether I have the exact figure here, but I think your figure is too high, Senator, and it will be very important to keep monitoring what is happening in this area.

answer.para: I think that the states are very keen to sign on to a Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. They wanted particularly to have long-term funding, which of course is what has been offered and accepted—the four-year term. That is very important for them in planning their future contracting arrangements. Some of the states want to sell some of their properties and exchange them for better located and newer properties. They want to have community housing take up some of the properties so that there is more of a mixture of types of housing in one area instead of the ghettos that were the fashion years ago. So the Commonwealth is very keen to work with them in that area to achieve better outcomes for people.

Some of the states have intimated that they in fact will not move to increasing rents for their tenants, as normally happens when tenants get an increase in income. Some have not made a decision on that yet. But I remind you that every payment that an income support person in public housing gets, whether it is rent assistance or whether it is the basic payment of age pension, Newstart or whatever, will go up by four per cent. People also have reduced tapers, which makes it much better; and as well families are of course getting substantial increases under the tax reform package. So people will be in a better position to meet what small cost increases there will be.

Let me say that we are talking about the transitional period here because, after the transitional period of the new tax reforms, the states will be in a substantially better financial position with a growth tax which they have never had before and which, over time, will mean billions of dollars of extra money going to them. I presume you are focusing on the transitional phase, during which, as I have pointed out to you, they will have some things that they provide as services to their people which will be reduced in cost and some, like housing, where there will be a small increase.

talk.start.para: —Madam President, I ask a supplementary question. I note the minister's admission that costs for state housing authorities to provide public and community housing will go up by some degree but that funding for the Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, which deals with this area of housing, will not, and that she notes the importance of having a long-term, four-year Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement. I ask the minister: if the states and the federal government are so keen to adopt a Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement, then why are we in April with no agreement having been reached and faced with the possibility of having yet another interim one-year agreement with the resultant uncertainty and restriction which that would cause? Is it not the case that some state governments at least, including coalition state governments, want to press the issue with the federal government of providing an adequate increase in Commonwealth-State Housing Agreement funding to ensure that there is not a net decrease in the value of funds available for public and community housing?

talker.name: Newman, Sen Jocelyn
Senator NEWMAN
talker.role: Family and Community Services; Minister Assisting the Prime Minister for the Status of Women

talk.start.para: —You asked so many questions in that, Senator, I do not think I have the time available to deal with them. Let me remind you that the housing ministers were trying to have a definitive outcome quickly from the federal government on this question and have been lobbying to have it dealt with at the housing ministers conference. That has not taken place because all of these transitional issues are being dealt with at the Premiers Conference, which is the appropriate place, because, as I pointed out to you, some of the services which states provide will reduce in cost to them and some will increase. That Premiers Conference will be held on 9 April, from memory, and I assume that the premiers, the Prime Minister and the Treasurer will come to agreements about the transitional arrangements at that time. You referred to a one-year contract. That is not in the interests of the states and I would not be endorsing it, either. (Time expired)

—Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the President's Gallery of a distinguished former President of the Senate, Sir Harold Young, a former senator from South Australia. I welcome you to the Senate.
—Hear, hear!

subdebateinfo.title: Civil Aviation Safety Authority: Flying Operations Inspectors

talk.start.para: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Regional Services, Senator Ian Macdonald. Is the minister aware that the Civil Aviation Safety Authority is now restructuring the positions of flying operations inspectors, who are responsible for regulating standards for Australian licensed pilots, to auditing positions? Is he aware that there will be no requirement for the flying operations inspectors to actually fly to assess pilot skills and operating standards but that they will simply audit from the ground an increasingly self-regulated and self-administered industry? When will the government step in to prevent any further erosion of the current levels of pilot and operating standards?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —I appreciate a question on aviation safety because it does enable me to indicate yet again the confidence the government has in the Civil Aviation Safety Authority and the Bureau of Air Safety Investigation. There were four parts to Senator O'Brien's question. Three of them asked whether I was aware of certain particular incidents. As it is not directly my portfolio, I cannot confess to being absolutely aware of the three matters, although I have read various newspaper reports. I can assure Senator O'Brien, though, that the Minister for Trans port and Regional Services, Mr Anderson, would be aware of those three issues that he raised.

answer.para: The fourth thing he asked was when the government was going to do something about it. Time and time again I suggest that the worst thing that could happen to air safety in Australia is if the likes of Senator O'Brien or me were to start directing air safety. That is a very technical job. It is a job for technical people to handle. Of course, CASA does have professional people, as does BASI. The government rightly leaves those very technical safety issues to the professionals, who are best able to deal with them.

talk.start.para: —I take it from that answer that the minister is saying that the government would not step in to prevent any further erosion of current levels of pilot and operating standards. If you do not know the answer to this next question, you might take it on notice. Are you aware that the International Civil Aviation Organisation is due to conduct an assessment of civil aviation safety management in Australia in August this year? Does the minister believe that ICAO will endorse the practice of flying operations inspectors being land based auditors?

talker.name: Macdonald, Sen Ian
Senator IAN MACDONALD
talker.role: Regional Services, Territories and Local Government

talk.start.para: —It is a hypothetical question to ask what I expect some international commission might determine at some time in the future. I am not allowed to answer that under Senate standing orders even were I minded to. But can I come back to the first part of Senator O'Brien's so-called supplementary question and repeat yet again that the government properly leaves matters of air safety to the professionals. The day we let Senator O'Brien and others start determining what professional air safety matters should be—
—Dick Smith?

—Dick Smith was a lot more professional than you, Senator. He knew a lot more about it. You come from the Transport Workers Union. I do not think you even had a truck licence, yet you were in the Transport Workers Union. Mr Dick Smith at least can fly, and he is a very able, very professional Australian. They are the sort of people that we do rely upon to keep our skies as safe as they are.
—Madam President, I ask that further questions be placed on the Notice Paper .

—Adding to an answer I gave to Senator Brown, I am pleased that today the Australian government has announced an immediate contribution of $2 million to humanitarian organisations in the Kosovo conflict: the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees, CARE Australia, the Australian Red Cross and World Vision Australia.
—I move:

speech.para: That the Senate take note of the answer given by the Minister for the Environment and Heritage (Senator Hill) to a question without notice asked by Senator Cook today, relating to the trade deficit.

In January Australia racked up a record current account deficit: it came in at $1.4 billion. In February we went one better. The current account deficit set another new high: it came in at $1.5 billion. This is a serious problem for Australia. It is a more serious and fundamental economic problem for Australia than fiddling with a new tax system. Let me quote what one of the more respected economic commentators, Alan Mitchell of the Australian Financial Review , said in his comment piece today. He said:
. . . yesterday's trade figures should serve as a warning.
He went on:
February's $1.5 billion deficit was not just a record; it was an unpredicted record.

talk.start.para: —Order! There is far too much noise in the chamber and there are far too many meetings taking place. If you wish to hold a meeting, please do so while you are seated or outside the chamber. I will have to start mentioning people's names if they do not start to resume their seats and hold conversations more quietly.
—He said that it caught the markets by surprise and went the other way to what the markets expected it would do. He also said:

speech.para: Access Economics made the point in its latest Economics Monitor : as well as a weakening terms of trade and an unusually large current account deficit, Australia will be one of the few industrialised countries with rising inflation.

Senator Hill, in answer to a serious question on this point, simply shrugged it off and falsely claimed credit, saying that the fundamental problem was the high domestic demand in Australia and that the government of which he is a part is responsible for so-called reforms that have led to this domestic demand. That is the big fallacy that the government wants to parade in Australia. The fundamental economic reforms in the Australian economy—let everyone be absolutely certain on this—were made by the previous Labor government when we floated the currency, restructured tariffs and undertook a number of other fundamental reforms; not just budget fiddling but fundamental economic change, the results of which are now being reaped by this government. That is the fundamental truth of the matter.

Senator Hill's explanation is like the shrug-off that the Treasurer, Mr Costello, gave on the Neil Mitchell program on 3AW last month. When confronted with the record figures, the Treasurer said, `Oh, I expected that.' It is a bit like hearing that the city of Los Angeles has just disappeared through the fault line in an earthquake and turning around to say, `Oh, I expected that.' It does not tell us one little thing about what the government is going to do about an economic problem that is quite serious and which stares Australia in the face as a problem we must confront. This is a serious problem which this government seems to want to ignore. The only explanation it puts forward—we heard this rubbish again today from Senator Hill—is to say that the GST will fix it. `The GST will fix it,' he said, and he went on parading this argument about input costs on exports. What Senator Hill does not tell anyone, what Senator Hill maybe does not know himself, is the impact of the GST on the exchange rate and the impact therefore of the GST on exports.

Of course input costs are reduced under their package but the exchange rate firms—according to the Department of the Treasury—by 3.5 per cent. In other words, the Australian dollar goes up and as a consequence of that our exports are more expensive in foreign markets than they are now. Tell that to the resource industry, which is facing price reductions everywhere. Tell that to the agricultural industry. Tell that to manufacturing exporters in this country. Tell that to the services sector, which is the biggest area of export growth. Their goods will cost more, therefore people overseas will buy less of them.

A definition of a current account deficit is an excess of national investment over national savings. There are two things that a government can do about rectifying the current account deficit. The first is to improve national savings. For this government that would mean to stop fiddling with Labor's changes to superannuation and enable workers and others in this country to save for their retirement, creating a pool of investment for national development. The second way of doing it would be to support export industries. You do that by not cutting $349 million out of trade programs in Australia; by not reducing Austrade, our export wing, through budget cuts of 30 per cent; and by not cutting the Export Market Development Grants Scheme by 25 per cent. Do something to help those companies in this country that want to improve our current account. (Time expired)

talk.start.para: —If most people listening to this debate have followed economic history in Australia in recent times, they would probably find it incredibly hilarious to hear a former member of the Keating cabinet, a close personal friend and supporter of the previous Prime Minister and Treasurer, lecturing a government that has turned Australia's economic circumstances around on current account deficits and economic management. When the history of Australia is written about this decade, about the previous government, the previous Prime Minister and Senator Cook—as one of the senior ministers in the later cabinet—it will be that of a government that took Australia to the brink of financial disaster.
—What a joke.

—The only thing that is a joke is the disgraceful economic management of the disgraced former governments. The Hawke and Keating governments were demonstrably, with probably the small exception of the Whitlam government, the worst economic managers in this nation's history.

speech.para: It is part of Australian history that the government led by Mr Gough Whitlam was the worst economic manager of Australia. Under it, interest rates, debt and inflation soared to levels never heard of before. There was only one other government that even came close to running up Australia's debt, interest rates, inflation rate and unemployment rates to the sorts of rates that we saw from the Whitlam government, and that was the government that Senator Cook was a part of. He sat around the cabinet table that made the decision to pull on the economic brakes to create an economic recession that saw hundreds of thousands of businesses and hundreds of thousands of households lose their jobs and lose their businesses.

What does Senator Cook now propose as the solution to Australia's current account deficit? Do you know what his solution is? He came in here today and said, `Why won't you spend more money?' That is the solution. It is not fundamental reform to our economic institutions. It is not for Labor to take on the hard decisions of reforming the tax system. At least to Mr Keating's credit he tried—when he was Treasurer—to reform the tax system. If you look at what Mr Keating said back in 1984 about the tax system, he saw that it was quite clear that Australia could not go into the next millennium—indeed the next decade, if you look at what he said—with a tax system designed in the 1930s.

In fact if you look at the previous government's record on privatisation, they knew very well back then that you could not go into the next decade, or even the next millennium, with major public businesses—such as Qantas and the Commonwealth Bank—and a range of such organisations in public ownership while running multi-billion-dollar deficits. But what did they do? They sold billions of dollars worth of assets.

They did that having deceitfully misled the Australian people at election after election. They went around saying, `We will never sell the Commonwealth Bank.' They promised the bank employees unions around the country that they would not sell the Commonwealth Bank. They looked at the union officials and, more importantly, at the bank employees who were members of those unions and said, `We won't sell the Commonwealth Bank but Mr Peacock or Dr Hewson will,' and then went off and sold a third of it. They said, `We will never sell any more than a third,' and then made it cabinet policy to sell the rest. Of course, we know that they held discussions—not very private any more—to go ahead and sell Telstra.

There is one thing that would have been sure if the party opposite, the Labor Party, had been re-elected in 1996 and that is that Telstra would have been sold by now, either in part or more likely broken up into small pieces and sold. So what is the coalition's solution to the current account deficit? It is to get public debt interest down so we are not paying $10 billion, year after year, in public debt interest to foreign bankers.

talk.start.para: —A GST, that is your solution.

—Yes, Senator Sherry, a GST is very much a part of the solution. You cannot trade your way out of a current account deficit problem with a tax system that puts $4½ billion worth of lead weight around our export industries. That is what the blokes and ladies opposite, Madam Deputy President, will do when they vote in coming months against a new tax system. That is to say, we have a choice: do we export to the world or do we put $4½ billion worth of lead weight around their necks? (Time expired)

—We are debating, in case those listening were not aware from Senator Ian Campbell's general waffle and irrelevant diatribe, yesterday's disastrous trade deficit figure—a record high of $1.5 billion. Senator Campbell chose to touch on history. Let me remind the Senate and those listening of a couple of other pieces of history. Which Prime Minister left Australia with the largest budget deficit in Australian history? It was John Howard. In 1983, when he was Treasurer, he left us with a budget deficit of $22 billion in today's money terms. Which Australian Prime Minister admitted to the media, about 18 months ago, that he had inherited an Australian economy basically in a sound condition? It was Mr Howard.

speech.para: We heard from Senator Hill today that the solution to our record trade deficit is tax reform, a goods and services tax. Let me say briefly why it is not a solution. Senator Cook touched on the issue of manufacturing exports. Certainly, a goods and services tax reduces the price of manufacturing exports and you sell more overseas. But the problem—the other side of the equation—is that the value of our dollar will go up, so there is no net gain from a goods and services tax for manufacturing exports.

Let me go to the largest single export earner in this country, tourism. It gets whacked by a GST. There is minimal impact on tourism from a wholesale sales tax. All of the economic modellers will argue and show that tourism is hit hard by a GST, and that is our greatest export earner at this point in time. There is one other very important reason why the goods and services tax and the government's tax package are not the solutions to our current trade deficit. The important issue in relation to a trade deficit is being able to fund it. How do you fund the borrowings required to fund the trade deficit so that it does not become unsustainable? There are two ways. The first is you fund it from national savings or, secondly, you borrow the money from overseas. The great problem we have with national savings is that our national savings are going down.
Senator Calvert interjecting—

talk.start.para: —You might scoff, but you should learn some basic economics, Senator Calvert. The problem with the government's tax package is that it reduces national savings. It gives tax cuts from a budget surplus but, if savings are to go up, every dollar from those tax cuts has to be saved. So Australians, if they are to rescue us from the record high trade deficit of $1.5 billion, will have to save every cent of their tax cuts in order to maintain national savings at their current levels, and obviously Australians will not do that. They will not save every cent of their tax cuts in order to support a record trade deficit.

speech.para: There is only one other solution, unfortunately, for Australia, and that is to import the capital to sustain a trade deficit of $1.5 billion a month. What is the consequence of importing the capital? We will obviously increase our deficit to the international community. That means overseas ownership of Australian resources will go up. So it is not correct to claim, as Senator Hill does, that the government's tax package, and particularly a GST, will do anything for savings. It in fact leads to a decrease in savings. It adds to the problem of our record trade deficit.

This government is fond of claiming credit, I think unfairly, for all economic news. Well, it can take the credit for a record trade deficit of $1.5 billion and the inevitable and very serious consequences for all Australians that will follow as a result of this record trade deficit. It is a disaster for the future of Australia. It is unsustainable. The government's policies do nothing to assist the trade deficit down and they do nothing for saving.

talk.start.para: —We have just heard a strong presentation from the Labor Party, from our colleague Senator Sherry. It was indeed very strong in terms of emotional content but rather limited in economic sense. The issue in Australia at the present time is that, despite difficulties in the Asian region, Australia has a very strong domestic economy. Having a strong domestic economy means that there is a very strong pull on imports into this country. Senator Sherry referred to Australia's ability to fund this deficit.
