talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Regional Council Election Amendment Rules (No. 2) 1998, made under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989, be disallowed.

In moving this disallowance motion, I will start by going to some of the history involved in this particular issue. The amendment which is the subject of this disallowance motion today is the result of a process set in motion following the 1996 round of ATSIC regional council and zone elections. The minister, in accordance with section 141 of the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act, convened a review panel on 3 March 1997 to review the ATSIC zone, regional and ward boundaries. The review panel, under the requirements of the act, comprised the ATSIC chair, Mr Djerkurra, a representative each from the Australian Electoral Commission and the Australian Surveying and Land Information Group, and two independent indigenous people—Associate Professor Eleanor Bourke of the University of South Australia and Ms Evelyn Scott, who is now the chair of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation.

The review panel subsequently made recommendations to introduce wards in the regions that were not currently divided. Its separate report on boundaries included draft boundary recommendations for nine out of the 10 regions not already divided into wards. There were a number of objections to the review panel recommendations and they were in fact lodged by or on behalf of regional councils in some seven of the nine cases where wards were to be introduced. In the Roma region in Queensland, the regional council and the local land council lodged two objections of identical substance. In the two cases where no objections were made—that is, the Sydney and Perth regions—the minister was required to give effect to the recommendations by tabling them in both houses of parliament within 15 sitting days. I do not know what happened there, but the minister tabled the rules amendment containing these two recommendations on the 16th sitting day, so of course they did not have effect.

As a result of the objections to the wards in seven regions, an augmented review panel comprising the membership of the original panel plus two more indigenous people, Mr Kerry Blackman and Mr Charles Coleman, was appointed by the minister. That panel substantially upheld the recommendations of the original review panel that wards should be introduced into all seven regions, and the minister was then required to give effect to those recommendations. The minister subsequently amended the regional council election rules to include these recommendations and tabled the amendments in both houses on 10 November 1998. The original two cases where objections were not lodged were included in the disputed recommendations because, as I have said, they had not been tabled in time, thus they ceased to have effect.

Notice of the disallowance motion was given by the opposition, by me, subsequent to representations from concerned ATSIC commissioners and regional councillors—those who were opposed to the recommendations of the review panels. It has to be put on the record that there were objections and concerns ranging across many reasons. The objections lodged with the review panels opposing the division of regional councils into wards were quite varied. There was concern, for instance, that the recommendations did not take account of the traditional Aboriginal relationships within the regions, that they were culturally inappropriate and that they did not reflect the full range of community opinion. Several of the objections opposed the specific boundaries of wards proposed by the review panels. Traditional boundaries had been largely ignored by the ward boundaries. There were also other objections related to the problems that the introduction of wards would place on councillors who had been transferred out of their proposed ward but were still within their region, for example, for employment purposes. In those cases, they would have to resign as councillors.

There were also further concerns contained in the objections that the introduction of the wards would divide councillors into ward `blocks', causing conflict over the division of resources within a particular region. It has to be said that there is a widely held belief that regional councils should reflect regional views, as is achieved by councillors being elected across a region rather than those being elected, as is proposed, to represent only a ward.

There has been some controversy about the position of ATSIC. When presented with the outcome of the review panel process, it is important to note that the overwhelming majority of the board of ATSIC, the peak representative body of indigenous Australians, opposed the recommendations of the review panels and that they in fact supported the objections lodged by the regional councils and local land councils. This position was reflected quite strongly towards the end of 1998 in the commission's decision No. 2160, after which the chairman, Mr Djerkurra, wrote to the minister expressing the board's opposition and extending an invitation to the minister to meet with a delegation of commissioners if necessary.
Mr Djerkurra subsequently wrote to the minister on 13 November 1998, expressing the board of commissioners' objections. I understand that in such correspondence Mr Djerkurra stated quite succinctly:

Commissioners firmly believe that the impact of having a system of wards within certain regions can be to encourage division within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community within those regions, and to foster a narrow, localised approach to decision making. Commissioners further believe that the introduction of multiple wards can act against the interests of minority groups within particular regions, making it harder for them to gain representation on Regional Councils.

Mr Djerkurra went on to give examples of the effect that the introduction of multiple wards would have in the Cairns region—a region of immediate concern in this debate—making it more difficult for Torres Strait Islanders, for instance, within that region to gain representation on the Cairns and District Regional Council. Mr Djerkurra pointed out:

Commissioners are also concerned that there has been insufficient attention given to traditional relationships between communities in certain regions in determining ward boundaries. As a result, many community members will be prevented from voting for representatives from their own "country", often because they have been forced to relocate away from their "country" by previous acts of State/Territory and Federal Governments.
So the board's concerns largely reflected those of the regional and land councils, all of whom continue to maintain a close grassroots association with their indigenous constituents.

The objections that were lodged with the review panels and the concerns of the board of commissioners must, I believe, be considered to be a reflection of indigenous Australians' sentiments on the matter. Gatjil Djerrkura himself alluded to the importance of giving due consideration to the objections to the recommendations of the review panels lodged by legitimately elected indigenous representatives in the report of the augmented review panel. As regional councils lodged nine of the total 13 objections, Gatjil Djerrkura noted in the report that he:

. . . was particularly concerned that due regard should be had to the views put forward by Regional Councils, their Chairpersons and Commissioners, as they have a duty to advocate for the best interests of their constituents and to reflect the community view on issues of importance.

Gatjil Djerrkura further expressed the view in his report that `in cases where the elected representatives indicated that they were expressing the majority view within the community, it would be right to accept that view'.

So we in the Senate are now confronted with a situation where it is indigenous people's view that this amendment will have the effect that they do not want. They want us to take into account the fact that they have enormous concerns about the amendments to the ATSIC regulations. As I say, we cannot underestimate the importance of those views from indigenous Australia, expressed by ATSIC and expressed also by regional councils. As recently as last week, a meeting of the Goolburri Land Council in Toowoomba, attended by some 530 of its members, substantially re-elected the previous land council board and voted down a proposal to introduce a ward system. We have a quite solid view expressed to us from indigenous Australia saying that they do not want the wards as suggested.

It is important to note in this debate that the opposition has always recognised that the minister has no discretion as to whether or not to give effect to the recommendations of the review panels. Under the act, the minister is obliged to give effect to those recommendations, regardless of his personal view. Despite the minister's accusations in his press release of 14 January this year, the opposition does understand and did understand that the minister must implement the recommendations of the panels. We have never sought to misrepresent the minister's views in respect to this. We accept that his responsibility is outside any discretionary power.

We do, however, take issue with the minister on the part that he played in misrepresenting the views of the board of commissioners concerning the review of ATSIC electoral boundaries when the issue gained significant media attention in January this year. In that same press release of 14 January that I mentioned earlier, the minister implied that the chair of the commission, Mr Djerrkura, had changed his position on the electoral review process since sitting on the panel. He accused Gatjil Djerrkura and Commissioner Ray Robinson, the deputy chair of the commission, together with Daryl Melham, the opposition spokesperson on those matters, of not understanding the act. I think that was an unfair assertion, and the facts do not support such an assertion.

To the contrary, it is quite important and informative for the Senate to note that during Senate estimates earlier this year the minister himself was asked if he had read the report of the augmented review panel. The minister replied that he had. He said that he had read it both subsequently and before he put out his press release. But if the minister had read that report, he would have noted that on page 3 of the report Mr Djerrkura specifically asked that his support for certain objections be noted. In fact, the report reads:

Mr Djerrkura's personal view was to accept the objections lodged against the proposals to introduce wards in Geraldton, Roma and Cairns Regions. This was on the basis of acceptance that the views expressed by the elected representatives in those areas should be regarded as reflecting the majority view of community members affected by the proposals.

Gatjil Djerrkura, on page 3 of the augmented review panel report, made his position clear. He clearly illustrated his disagreement with the rest of the panel, for all who may have read that report to see. In that respect, the minister, who states he read the report, should have been able to note Mr Djerrkura's concern. In effect, the panel had overruled Mr Djerrkura's position. If the minister had read the report, he would not have gone on to misrepresent Mr Djerrkura's position. He would not have gone on to state in his press statement of 14 January that he was surprised at the calls by Gatjil Djerrkura and his deputy, Sugar Ray Robinson, for the government to reject recommendations to introduce a ward system.

The story does not end there. The deception of the minister extends even further. Not only did Mr Djerrkura express his objections to the introduction of wards in that report but also he actually had written to the minister some two months before the press statement. He wrote to the minister on 13 November 1998 expressing the opposition to the introduction of wards of the board of commissioners, a board of which Mr Djerrkura is a member and an appointee of the minister. So the minister said in estimates committee hearings that he had read the report beforehand, the minister received correspondence two months before the press statement, but it did not stop the minister from misrepresenting Mr Djerrkura's position. Minister, I have got to say that, in terms of defences and excuses, yours go down in history, I reckon. When you were asked about the accuracy of your press release, your only excuse was:
It all happens pretty quick in this game. Within seconds of it hitting the fan I have to respond.

Things do happen very quickly in this game for all of us. That is why we try to read, prepare and be accurate in what we present to the public and to the Senate. So you should not have been expressing surprise at Mr Djerrkura's position, Minister. You should have known that position; it had already been put to you.

I will not go on for much longer, other than to state that this is an issue which has raised a lot of interest in ATSIC and indigenous Australia. Because of the concerns mentioned earlier, indigenous Australians have a real concern about this ward proposal being accepted by the parliament. As I said earlier, this disallowance motion has the overwhelming support of the majority of the ATSIC board and has the overwhelming support of indigenous communities who would be affected most by the amendment's provisions. As I cited earlier, the Goolburri Land Council in Toowoomba had some 530 of its members attending a public meeting on the Saturday before last, substantially re-electing the previous board and voting down the proposal that had been put before them to introduce wards. Given the clear voice of indigenous Australians and given the implications some of these ward divisions would have, I urge senators to basically reflect the aspirations and the will of indigenous Australians by voting for the disallowance motion which I introduced this afternoon.

talker.name: Herron, Sen John
Senator HERRON
talker.role: Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs

talk.start.para: —I wish to state at the outset that the rules Labor is seeking to disallow today have not come from the government, and Senator Bolkus has mentioned that. They are the result of an independent process involving indigenous Australians and they stem directly from amendments to electoral rules brought forward under the previous Labor government. Labor's position today is totally indefensible. I would urge the Democrats, the Greens and Senator Harradine to listen carefully to what I have to say and to consider the facts before deciding how they will vote on this issue, and I am happy to respond to the charge that Senator Bolkus has just made in relation to this matter.

speech.para: The Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Regional Council Election Amendment Rules (No. 2) 1998 which we are considering today provide for the introduction of multiple wards into a number of ATSIC regions. The motion to disallow these amendments—as I have stated—is misguided. It is obvious from Senator Bolkus's contribution that it is based on misinformation, and I do not blame him for that. To make an informed decision on the implementation of these amendments it is essential to understand the purpose behind them and the purpose which gave rise to them. This will clearly indicate that the rules before us were drafted in accordance with the law and in accordance with the wishes of the ATSIC electorate. These wishes were made clear in comprehensive public consultations.

The ATSIC Act requires that, after each ATSIC election, there is an independent review of its electoral processes and boundaries. The review of the 1996 election found that communities in regions not already divided into wards were potentially disadvantaged. The demographics of the region could mean that the interests of some groups were not represented on the regional council and, in the interests of a more equitable representation, the independent review recommended the introduction of wards into nine more regions. For those unaware of the fact, the ward system already applies in 25 of the 35 ATSIC regions for the very purpose of providing fairer representation. Senator Bolkus did not mention that. They already exist, so the principle is well established in 25 of the 35 ATSIC regions.

Let us deal with the process. We can have every confidence in the expertise of the review panel, which included the Chairman of ATSIC, the Electoral Commission and the Australian Surveying and Land Information Group. The review panel were ex officio Mr Gatjil Djerrkura, the Chairman of ATSIC; Mr Kerry Heisner, the Australian electoral officer nominated by the Australian Electoral Commissioner to represent the commission; and Mr Doug White, Manager of the Public Interest Mapping Program of the Australian Surveying and Land Information Group, nominated by the General Manager of the group to represent the organisation. My ministerial appointees were Ms Evelyn Scott, who is Chairperson of the Cairns and District Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Corporation of Women and is now Chairman of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation, and Associate Professor Eleanor Bourke, Director of the Aboriginal Centre of Excellence, University of South Australia. I do not think anybody could disagree with the quality of that panel.

This panel did not reach its conclusions in isolation. It consulted widely with the ATSIC electorate in reaching its determinations, and the results of its consultations are reflected in those determinations. That was only the first part of the process. The review panel published its conclusions and there was an opportunity for public comment and objections. Following the 1996 report there were indeed some objections to the introduction of multiple wards in some regions. Because of those objections, the next step in the required process was undertaken—and I have no discretion in this, it is required to be done—and two additional members were required to be brought onto the panel and another round of public consultations was conducted. The two additional appointments that I made were Mr Charles Coleman, who is a member of the Torres Strait Islander Advisory Board, and Mr Kerry Blackman, a member of the Council for Aboriginal Reconciliation. So the augmented panel obviously had a majority of Aboriginal people on it.

This augmented panel made some variations to boundaries but largely confirmed the original findings. Its recommendations were incorporated into draft regulations under the ATSIC Act which I approved. It is important to note that I take no part in determining the content of the regulations. By law I must give effect to the augmented review panel's decisions on wards. I have no discretion to vary its recommendations, and I agree with that. It is those recommendations made by the independent augmented review panel, the expertise of which is beyond question, which are embodied in the rules now before us.

I think the confusion that arose in relation to the different accounts that Senator Bolkus gave was that, on the one hand, Mr Djerrkura signed off on both the review panel and the augmented review panel but, on the other, did not put in a dissenting report. But, as Senator Bolkus quite rightly said, in the minutes of the meeting he voiced his dissent in the original review panel. I do not know how many meetings he actually attended, but he did in that instance review that but did not sign a dissenting report. He signed off on both the original report and the review panel.

I would like to recount briefly some ATSIC electoral history that bears on this issue. The first electoral review was conducted after the 1993 ATSIC elections. That review received no objections—none whatsoever—to the ward system which was already operating in 23 of the 35 regions. It did receive representations to extend the ward system into three more regions prior to the 1996 elections. An amendment to the ATSIC Act reduced the size of regional councils. Where there had been between 10 and 20 members, depending on population, there would now be between eight and 12.

This gave rise to concern that through that amendment some community groups would find themselves unrepresented. Therefore an amendment was made to the ATSIC Act to require the electoral review panel to look specifically at ways to accommodate the interests of distinct groups. As we now know, the review panel examining the 1996 election recommended more wards as a way of addressing this issue. That was the principle that was espoused. It was accepted by both the review panel and the augmented review panel, and—as I have mentioned—I have no discretion in that in bringing it to the Senate. As I have mentioned, I know that the ATSIC chairman is opposed to the introduction of wards in some regions. His views were set out in the report of the augmented review panel. I should point out that most of the objections to the introduction of new wards came from regional councils.

The chairman maintains that if regional councillors indicate that they are reflecting a majority view of the community then we should accept that. I find this perhaps a little naive. Firstly, there is a very low turnout for ATSIC elections—around 25 per cent of eligible voters. So there is no guarantee that councillors are expressing a majority view. Secondly, it would be hard to guarantee that councillors had entirely laid aside any self-interest in their submissions to the review. It would be natural for them to take that into account. In fact, if we follow the chairman's argument to its logical conclusion, we would not bother with the review and its attendant public consultation, we would merely ask the regional councils for their views. I do not think Senator Bolkus has reflected that in his interpretation.

It would be like allowing the members of the House of Representatives to draw their own electoral boundaries. That is what it is. It was Senator Bolkus who put forward the proposition that we should just follow what the regional councils have told us. So that is the analogy: we would be asking them to determine their own boundaries and electoral rules. The Labor Party brought forward this ATSIC legislation to have a review panel and then an augmented review panel.

The problems with the ATSIC elected arm's views are illustrated disturbingly in the augmented review's account of its meeting in the very region that Senator Bolkus referred to, the Goolburri region. The panel was moved to note that the zone commissioner made strong representations to have a particular public meeting cancelled. The panel also noted that meetings in this region were characterised by aggressive and intimidating behaviour by some participants and that the panel was subject to personal abuse and insults by members of the regional council. That is in the minutes. We cannot in the circumstances therefore share the chairman's confidence as to the impartiality of the regional councillors.

There is another important point in relation to these amendments that is very important in our consideration today. The amendments include the introduction of the ward system into four regions. No objections were lodged to the proposal for a ward system in those four regions. Indeed, there is clear evidence of strong community support for the new arrangements in these regions. If these amendments are disallowed, these regions will not get the changes that they want to better reflect the composition of their community. Obviously, the desire of four regions to have a ward system introduced has been totally disregarded in Senator Bolkus's statement.

These amendments were drafted in accordance with legislation. ATSIC electoral rules and boundaries have been reviewed and amended over the years, beginning in 1993, to accommodate the emerging needs of the indigenous community. These amendments reflect the findings of the latest review. The review and the subsequent augmented review involved wide and comprehensive public consultation. The government has had no influence on the process and I, as minister, must give effect to the review panel's deliberations. We cannot guarantee that views put forward by ATSIC regional councillors are entirely free of self-interest. It may well be that some stand to lose at the next election because of the introduction of the ward system.

There are regions which unequivocally support the introduction of wards which will miss out if the amendments are disallowed. As I said at the outset, I believe the motion to disallow these rules is misguided and not based on a proper understanding of the process, of the legislation governing it or of my role. I urge the Senate to allow these rules to be implemented in line with the law and the wishes of the wider indigenous community.

talk.start.para: —This disallowance motion relates to the introduction of a ward system for elections to the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission. The commission is the elected representative body for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people. As such, it is of utmost importance that the system for the conduct of ATSIC elections be the best possible, the fairest possible and the most culturally appropriate.

speech.para: I do not know if the current electoral system for ATSIC meets those criteria but I am in no doubt that the changes proposed by the government will not help. In fact, they have the potential to do great harm. They have been the subject of considerable debate both within and outside the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community.

The ATSIC board of commissioners, which should be the minister's primary source of advice on this issue, has serious concerns about the proposed introduction of the ward system under the amended rules. Those concerns have been conveyed to the minister, and I am very concerned that he has chosen to ignore them on this occasion.

The chair of ATSIC, Mr Gatjil Djerrkura, pointed out in a letter to the minister in November last year that the board maintained strong objections to the introduction of wards where significant community opposition existed. The minister said that no objections were lodged, and all I have to say to that is that there has been a raft of attacks on the various rights, the lifestyle, the environment, the culture and so on of Aboriginal people. As if these people do not have enough to do and as if they have the resources to be involved in paper warfare. I find it rather annoying that the only way an objection could be considered real is if they had lodged it in writing to the minister.

The commissioners firmly believe that the impact of having a system of wards within these regions will encourage division within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community, and I agree with them. The question is whether this was the intention of the minister. You do not need to be cynical to think that that might possibly be the case; you only have to look at the history of the government on any aspect of Aboriginal affairs that has come before the parliament in recent times.

ATSIC commissioners have also told the minister that the introduction of multiple wards can act against the interests of minority groups within particular regions, making it harder for them to gain representation on regional councils. Again, I agree with them. It is a bit like the debate we were having yesterday. The fact that this change has been pushed onto some regions does not mean that it makes it fair to push it onto others. By way of example, I draw attention to the implications of the proposals for ATSIC elections in my state of Western Australia.

In the augmented review panel report on this matter, the chair of ATSIC specifically said that no wards should be introduced in the Geraldton region. He did so because of concerns expressed by community members. It is my understanding his comments were made in the general section of that report because there is no capacity to file a dissenting report. Senator Bolkus was interjecting on this issue. It is perfectly fair that the interjection should be registered because Senator Herron was suggesting that, because no dissenting report was filed, that meant there was agreement. If there is no legal capacity to file a dissenting report, how dare a minister come into this place and suggest that the absence of a dissenting report indicates assent?

It is all very well for the minister to argue that this is an ATSIC report, but clearly there is still division over these matters. Mr Djerrkura has sought to highlight these divisions. The minister's proposal will see five wards in the Geraldton region, which will split the community and make it very much harder for minority views—or smaller, more dispersed communities and groups—to be represented. Once again, Senator Herron has said there will be regions which miss out. Senator Herron is possibly not fully understanding the situation where a number of groups span more than one region in geographical terms. The reality is that we are not talking about a European Australian concept of location, as we would do in normal wards for council elections in Australia; we are talking about culturally appropriate groupings.

This likely under-representation is very pronounced in North Queensland where the present deputy chair of the regional council is a Torres Strait Islander. Dividing up Cairns into wards will make it almost impossible for her to be preselected. There will not be enough Torres Strait Islanders in any one ward. It will effectively mean that Torres Strait Islanders who make up a significant proportion of the population in Cairns will not have enough numbers in any one ward to elect any representatives. As well as depriving them of representation, it will also lead to fewer even bothering to take part in the elections, we believe. After all, why would you, if you knew your preferred candidate was not even running in your ward?

The minister is also clearly wrong in comments about how representative the Chairman of ATSIC is when he speaks about these things. Senator Herron told the Senate on 10 March that only 25,000 people voted in ATSIC elections. In this, he is quite simply wrong. The actual figures, which were provided to the minister in a brief after the 1996 elections, indicate that 49,812 people voted to elect the 375 councillors—almost 50,000, twice the number Senator Herron told the Senate. In fact, voter turnout when compared with other voluntary voting elections is actually quite respectable. It compares favourably with local government elections in Australia and even compares favourably with elections for the United States Congress. So when Senator Herron gets advice from the elected chair of ATSIC that wards should not be introduced across the board, Senator Herron should listen, we believe, and take note.

By contrast with the very reasonable turnout at the elections, turnout for the meeting to discuss the review of electoral matters which led to these changes was rather less representative. In Geraldton the number was 10, in Shark Bay it was 15—hardly an indication that there was much concern about the existing system and certainly not in any way, shape or form a mandate for this change.

The chair of ATSIC, Mr Djerrkura, expressed the view that it may be worth the government considering deferring consideration of these proposals. As he says, there is no urgency about them. There could easily be an independent investigation of the various matters in dispute and a better electoral system could be the result in time for the next ATSIC elections.

Finally, I want to reiterate the point about the division in the community which is likely to be caused by this action. Surely the minister can see this potential division. It has been pointed out to him in no uncertain manner—not only by ATSIC commissioners themselves but by community organisations around the country. Why does he continue to pursue this course if it is not his aim to foster this division?

I can understand the statement `I have no choice', but Senator Herron made his appointments to this panel. We must not let the government further weaken the ability of Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people to speak with a united voice on issues on which they find themselves in conflict with the government. We believe this is an effort to do so. We must vote to disallow this change.

talk.start.para: —In a moment I am going to seek leave to incorporate most of my speech, because I am conscious of how much business we are still trying to get through. I assure the Senate that the speech canvasses much the same material and areas as Senator Bolkus and Senator Margetts have canvassed. I shall also seek leave to table a letter from the Queensland State Advisory Committee of ATSIC.

speech.para: I make a couple of quick comments. It is very true that over this issue there is very great division in the Aboriginal community. I regret that sometimes this government does not seem to understand the need to heal Aboriginal community divisions, not to make them worse. One of the things we must all learn and certainly stick to is that we should never play off one group of Aboriginal people against another.

I thank the minister for the briefing that his department gave me. It was very comprehensive and canvassed most of the issues he raised in his speech. But I have to say that on balance the Democrats are prepared to accept the reasons given by the majority of ATSIC commissioners, who did speak to me on a number of occasions. I have read the material they gave me, which was very extensive, and I believe that on balance the Democrats will support this disallowance motion. I seek leave to table a letter from the Queensland State Advisory Committee under the signature of Commissioner Terry O'Shane and to incorporate my speech in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows—
The proposed amendments were tabled in both houses of parliament by the Minister for Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Affairs, Senator John Herron, on November 10 last year.
They seek to introduce a system of electoral wards into a number of ATSIC regions.
They have since been the subject of considerable debate, both within and outside, the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community.
The ATSIC Board of Commissioners has serious concerns about the proposed introduction of the ward system to these regions under the amended rules.
These concerns were conveyed to the Minister in November last year by way of a letter from the Chairman, Mr Gatjil Djerrkura.
The Chairman pointed out in that letter that the board maintained strong objections to the introduction of wards where significant community opposition existed.
Commissioners firmly believe that the impact of having a system of wards within these regions will encourage division within the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander community.
It will foster a narrow, localised approach to decision making.

The Commissioner further feels that the introduction of multiple awards can act against the interests of minority groups within particular regions, making it harder for them to gain representation on regional councils.

For example Commissioner Terry O'Shane has pointed out that the proposed division of Cairns into four wards will make it more difficult for members of the Torres Strait Islander community in that region to gain representation on the Cairns and District Regional Council.
Commissioners are also concerned that insufficient attention has been paid to traditional relationships between communities in certain regions in determining ward boundaries.

As a result many community members will be prevented from voting for representatives from their own `country' often because they have been forced to relocate away from their traditional lands by previous acts of state, territory and federal governments.

Senator Herron was informed in November last year by the ATSIC Chairman that a number of commissioners would be making representations to a number of members of parliament seeking their support to disallow the amendments because of these concerns.

He made the point that the board recognised the minister was required by the act to give effect to the recommendations arising from a section 141 review and expressed the hope he would understand, and accept as legitimate, the reasons for the opposition of those commissioners to the introduction of wards into various regions.
Unfortunately the minister seriously misrepresented this position when this matter became the subject of media debate earlier this year.
The media debate was initiated when a number of journalists contacted a number of commissioners following the tabling of the motion of disallowance by Senator Bolkus.
The Minister issued a press release on January 14 this year which stated the Chairman had twice signed off, as Chair of the section 141 review panel, on the `unanimous' recommendations of the panel.
The statement claimed Mr Djerrkura, amongst others, was not aware of the minister's duty to follow the legislative provisions of the act.
This is not true.
Mr Djerrkura issued a statement on the same day to clarify the situation.
They freely acknowledge there are divisions among Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people on these matters in some regions.
It is their view the introduction of wards works in some areas.
It clearly does not in others.
This, in my view, is a powerful argument against adopting the proposed changes, not an argument for them.
Let there be absolutely no doubt about this matter.
I have a copy of a resolution, which I would seek to table, from a meeting in September last year of ATSIC's state advisory committee in Queensland.
The SAC, as it is known, is the pre-eminent forum for elected ATSIC representatives in that state. . . it represents all regional council chairs and commissioners.
The resolution relates to its consideration of the section 141 review of the ATSIC electoral boundaries.

It states, in part, that although it recognises that the ward system may have some application in the major urban regions due to the homogenous nature of the indigenous population in those regions, it overwhelmingly rejects the imposition of wards into ATSIC regions.
It considers the introduction of the ward system, as proposed in these regional council rules amendments, to be a retrograde step.
It raises a number of other disturbing issues in relation to the consultation process which I do not intend to canvass in this debate.
I am aware of suggestions the disallowance motion will have the effect of overturning recommendations in other areas which have strong community support.
This argument does not stand up to scrutiny.
New rules can be made within six months after the date of disallowance covering those elements of the disallowed rules which the House considers should be allowed to come into effect.
In other words the Minister could simply seek to return to the Senate those elements of this package he believes has majority support.

In my view there is also absolutely no need for urgency in relation to any subsequent actions by the Minister in this regard in relation to the prospect that the regional council elections are scheduled to be held in October this year.
I am informed the Australian Electoral Commission and the administrative arm of ATSIC have recently advised the Howard government that those elections should be suspended until next year.
This follows real concerns expressed by the AEC that there could be significant problems attached to holding those elections so close to the proposed referendum in November.
I am also informed the administrative arm of ATSIC supports the AEC's concerns in this regard.

They have advised the government that they support the Electoral Commission's view that the ATSIC elections should be held next year to ensure a positive outcome from both the referendum and the ATSIC election.
I trust the government will accept the advice from both the AEC and ATSIC given the need to ensure the highest possible turnout to both.

I am aware that the minister has suggested the view of the ATSIC Chairman that the regional council submissions should be taken as representative of the whole electorate is untenable given the low voter turnout in ATSIC elections.
I find this offensive.
This is not what the Chairman said.
He said quite clearly in the report that where those regional councillors could demonstrate they were expressing the majority view they should be listened to.
In any case there is a simple solution available to those who disagree with regional councillors or commissioners who seek to misrepresent the views of their communities in these matters.
They simply vote them out. . . .as we do in our electoral matters.

One would assume the minister would be seeking to suspend the ATSIC elections and joining with the commission in seeking to bolster the turnout of voters rather than using a perceived low turnout as a point of argument against elected commissioners.
One would imagine the minister could also use such an extension of time to carefully re-examine the proposals he has presented here.

talk.start.para: —The Senate is debating a motion moved by Senator Bolkus that the Regional Council Election Amendment Rules (No. 2) 1998, made under the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Commission Act 1989, be disallowed. As has been stated in this debate, these rules have been made by the minister in a manner that he had no discretion about. This was in accordance with the provisions of the act.

speech.para: I first want to say that I am very grateful for the people who have given information to me about this matter. I recognise that I have had representations on this matter from the ATSIC chair, from certain other members of ATSIC and from a group led by Commissioner Ray Robinson, and I also have had a couple of pieces of correspondence, including from the Central Queensland Regional Council. I appreciate receiving that information. I would like now, however, to examine what we are faced with and what I in particular am faced with, because I understand that this is a matter that will come down to my vote.

I have listened carefully to Senator Bolkus. He would understand that I give considerable weight to what the ATSIC chair has to say and to what ATSIC has to say. I also listened to what Senator Herron said. I think he outlined the case for the government quite well. I also listened to what Senator Margetts and Senator Woodley had to say. In the situation I am faced with, not only I myself but also every other member of the Senate must consider whether the procedures that are outlined in the ATSIC Act have been followed rigidly and in accordance with the legislation.

As honourable senators know, there is a requirement under the act to have an independent review panel established within 90 days of the ATSIC election, and this in fact did occur on this occasion. That independent review panel was established, and I acknowledge what Senator Herron said. I do not think anybody would question the integrity of the people on that panel. I did not hear in any of the advice given to me from all quarters that there was any such objection to the people who had been appointed to the independent review panel in accordance with the legislation.

Indeed, from 29 March 1997, the panel published notices in 54 newspapers and periodicals nationally, inviting submissions. There was of course a notice in the Gazette, for those who might read the Gazette—and obviously regional councils would and did. In addition to that, the panel sent out about 2,500 letters to all regional councillors. On the matter of the 2,500 letters, I might just digress by saying that my office gets a fairly large number of letters, and one day it actually peaked at 2,500. I thought I would not let the opportunity pass to say that. So there were 2,500 letters sent out, but the significance of this is that all regional councils and all members of the Torres Strait Regional Authority and all recognised indigenous organisations received that letter. Resulting from the publicity, 29 submissions were received within the due date of the 90-day statutory limit, but late submissions were accepted by the independent review panel.

The minister has indicated that the review panel did examine the representation of the distinct groups, consistent with the provision of section 141(6) of the act. It is interesting to note that the panel considered that, while it was not possible generally to ensure the representation on regional council of all groups, it was possible to try and ensure that the interests of all groups were represented. It is not possible on the one hand to ensure the representation of all groups on the region council; that is clearly not possible. But it is important to ensure that the interests of all the groups are represented.

The panel, in its review, indicated that there was a potential disadvantage for groups in regions not divided into wards and it decided to put the issue to public consultation meetings. These took place, and 23 consultation meetings were held, covering all affected regions. I am outlining this because it is most difficult—in fact, impossible—in my position to challenge the legality of what has happened, and it is very difficult to question that the independent review committee has acted in the best possible manner in which a review panel should act.

The panel published in the Gazette and in the press a notification of the processes for objections, and there were 13 objections, as Senator Bolkus indicated. Under the act, the minister can convene the augmented panel, and that has been referred to before. But what has not been referred to is that the augmented panel conducted a number of open public consultations at eight locations.

As a result of all of this—to cut a long story short—the augmented independent review panel made its final recommendations in June last year. They were published in the press and the Gazette. They were provided to the minister in early July. As has been stated in this chamber, the minister has no discretion in this matter. I am, therefore, in no position to criticise the minister because his statutory obligation is to make rules in accordance with the recommendations of the augmented panel—that is, if there are objections to the independent review panel's recommendations. All the procedures have been undertaken.

In those circumstances, what is the alternative? I am not convinced, and I certainly have not been convinced—quite the contrary—that the views that have been expressed to me by those groups that I mentioned are the unanimous views of Aboriginal people—far from it. It has been indicated by the minister that there would be considerable disenfranchisement of a number of groups if the panel's final recommendations are not accepted, or if the rules are disallowed by this chamber.

The alternative is to say, `The ATSIC board of council can veto it.' There is no such provision in the legislation for a veto. What we are being asked to do is to say, `Accept that the ATSIC board of commissioners have, in effect, a veto.' That is not in the legislation. All of the provisions of the legislation have been observed meticulously. Under those circumstances, I propose to vote against the disallowance motion.
Question put:
That the motion (Senator Bolkus's ) be agreed to.

division.result.para: Question so resolved in the negative.

talk.start.para: —by leave—I wish to correct a statement which I made previously. I am indebted to Senator Margetts, who has provided me with a document from the Townsville regional office of the Queensland State Advisory Committee in which the chairperson of the regional council and Commissioner Rosendahl had this to say:

speech.para: In addition, the State Advisory Committee takes strong exception to the flawed consultation process undertaken by the review team and believes that the very small number of people consulted the obvious conflict of interests of some of the panel members and the failure of the review team to acknowledge the formal review of regional council places serious doubt over the accuracy of the review findings.

In the prior debate, I mentioned that I had not heard that anybody had impugned or challenged any member of the review panel. Clearly, in this particular case there is a suggestion of conflict of interest of some of the panel. I am not sure of the details, but I thought I would put that into the record.

talk.start.para: —I move:

speech.para: That the Migration Amendment Regulations 1998 (No. 8), as contained in Statutory Rules 1998 No. 285 and made under the Migration Act 1958, be disallowed.
As I understand, we will not be rising tonight until we come to a vote on this issue. Is that correct, or will we have to try to finish this by 7.20 p.m.?

talk.start.para: —Senator, I do not think we have been so advised.

—Okay. I wanted to get clarification on that because, as senators may be aware, this is the final day that this disallowance motion can be debated and determined under whatever arcane legal requirements we have that govern these things.
—It is not arcane; you have delayed it.

—I have not delayed it. Under the law as it stands, if a motion is not voted on by the time 15 sitting days expire from when it was first given, then the regulations are taken to be disallowed. My view is very much that I do not want a regulation to be disallowed purely because time expired for consideration of it. I put on the record the fact that I was ready for this to be debated more than a week ago. If we have to finish this by 7.20 p.m., then I will be very brief at this stage. Hopefully, other senators will likewise be brief because I do not wish to have a disallowance go through purely because of an expiry of time. I think that is a very inappropriate way for any regulation or disallowable instrument to be disallowed.

speech.para: At this stage I will just give a brief outline. The migration amendment regulation that is contained in statutory rules No. 285 makes it harder for parents to migrate to Australia. While the first instalment of the visa application charge for onshore applicants in this category has remained unchanged at $1,060, the second instalment has increased from $945 per person to $5,000 per adult person and $945 per person under 18 years old. The assurance of support bond has also risen from $3,500 for the main applicant and $1,500 per additional adult to $4,000 for the main applicant and $2,000 per additional adult. This money continues to be refunded after two years if social security benefits have not been accessed.

Applicants under this new parent category are accorded a higher priority than those under the old subclass. One of the areas of concern to the Democrats is that those people who can afford the increased amounts that are required under the visa application charge and the assurance of support bond basically get into the fast lane while the rest have to wait in the longer queue. A very simple—but I imagine quite easy to comprehend—analogy would be people in a long line queuing to get into the movies, the footy or whatever, and having to wait and potentially miss out because they are too far back in the queue. But if they pay double the price then they are able to jump into the fast lane and get in. In the Democrats' view, that is not a desirable approach to public policy.

We believe that, in some circumstances, the aspect of applicants under this category having to apply from offshore and no longer being able to apply onshore may also generate some problems. We think it is inappropriately inflexible as well. The very large hike in fees and charges for the new parent/aged dependent relative categories will make it virtually impossible in some cases for parents to apply. The Democrats feel the changes open Australia's immigration law up to the charge of being directed more towards the rich and discriminating against the poor and underprivileged.

The Democrats believe that in an area such as parent reunions, which is very different from skilled migration or business migration, we should not have too high a high-jump bar or a hurdle for people purely on the basis of their income. In addition, people able to pay the new increased charges have been placed at the top of the processing queue, while those unable to afford these charges but have lodged applications at an earlier time have slipped back in the queue. We believe this is fundamentally unfair.

Because I am trying to be brief I will just raise one other point, which will enable other senators to put forward their views on the disallowance motion. I have said a number of times in this place that, broadly speaking, I find the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, reasonably willing to enter into negotiations to consider different views and concerns that senators and the community have about approaches that he is considering taking. I do not want to make this sound like a blanket statement but I have been somewhat disappointed that the main response from the minister on this regulation has been basically to threaten that if the Senate passes this disallowance motion then his response will be to further slash the parent reunion program from the current level of 2,800 per year to around 500 per year, which will obviously significantly increase the waiting period even further. For 1998-99 the government has capped the parent subclass at about 2,800 places.

As I said, the minister's response to the concerns that have been put forward not only from the Democrats but also from the community about this measure has been to say, `If you don't like it and you knock it off, I will put in an incredibly tight cap of only 500. And then I will tell the community that it is all the Senate's fault or the Democrats' fault or my fault or whoever's fault.' I am not overly impressed with that as an appropriate way of deciding public policy outcomes.

I would say that if at the end of the day—to use a cliche—the minister decides to introduce a cap of 500 per year in the parent reunion program, then that is the minister's decision. It is not a decision of the Senate. We are only able to debate and consider proposals put forward by the government, by the executive, on their face value. That is what the Democrats are doing in relation to this regulation.

If the minister wants to respond by introducing another measure that is even more draconian than that, then that is on his head and that is for him to justify. It is the parliament's role and duty to assess disallowable instruments, and to decide whether they are appropriate public policy—whether they are appropriate under the broad range of measures, such as fairness and equity, that we have to consider. I think the parliament will make a decision based on those sorts of grounds. If the minister wants to respond by introducing a further unfair measure, then that is for him to decide and for him to justify.

talk.start.para: —The opposition supports the motion moved by Senator Bartlett to disallow Migration Amendment Regulations 1998 (No. 8), as contained in Statutory Rules 1998 No. 285 and made under the Migration Act 1958. These regulations are a response to perceived direct costs associated with family reunion migration, particularly for parents over the age of 45. The opposition believes the government cost analysis is narrowly focused on direct and short-term profit and loss considerations.

speech.para: We have a number of reasons for opposing these regulations. Senator Bartlett has already outlined a number of reasons, with which we would agree. Firstly, the total cost of sponsoring two parents to Australia under these new rules is about $17,000, which includes the application fee, social security bond, health levy plus air fares. Under the new regulation, the new aged parent visa subclass will be given priority in processing, even ahead of parent visa applications lodged years ago. This is in fact queue jumping and discriminates against poorer applicants, which is very inequitable.

Under the new regulation no other reunion of parents with their adult children or grandchildren will be possible until the parents reach retirement age. This will deprive Australian families of the direct and valuable supportive role of parents and grandparents which helps to stabilise families.

Under the new regulation the old pipeline, which currently stands at approximately 17,500, will be allowed to either stagnate or will be abandoned altogether. A token allowance of 25 per cent of total annual parent intake has been earmarked for the old pipeline—about 700 places on last year's figures. This is a totally inappropriate measure as the current intake levels indicate that it would take over 25 years to clear the backlog. For those reasons, and in view of the time, the opposition strongly opposes these regulations and urges the Senate to throw them out.

talk.start.para: —It is my strong view, as I have expressed time and time again, that anyone lawfully resident in this country has the right to have their family with them. In my view, these regulations are inconsistent with my longstanding position on the importance of a fair and equitable family reunion program. Family migration, family reunion and the refugee and humanitarian programs should be the cornerstone of our policy. Australia's migration program should be based on the principles of non-discrimination on the grounds of race, nationality, ethnic origin, membership of a particular social group or political opinion, religion, language, gender, disability, age and socioeconomic background. Giving people preferential treatment because of their socioeconomic background, as the government is proposing, goes against these principles.

speech.para: These regulations create a subclass of visas for applicants who are able to jump ahead in the very long queue for parent visas because they have the financial means to do so. Those with the money get here quicker, those who do not have the money must continue to wait in line for what seems to be an ever dwindling number of places.

In November 1998 the government introduced a massive increase in application fees, health levies and assurance of support requirements for parents. This has virtually doubled the cost of sponsoring both parents to Australia. The new visa category requires fees of $4,000 for a single and $6,000 for a couple. Applicants also have to provide a medical bond of $5,000 towards their Medicare costs, up from $940 for normal parent reunion. The assurance of support compulsory bond increases from $3,500 for main applications plus $1,500 per additional adult to $4,000 for main applicant and $2,000 per additional adult. The huge increases in the second instalment of the visa application charge plus increased bonds mean parent migration is a financial impossibility for many Australian families.

I am concerned about the message this sends about the government's suggestion that it is pro-family in this regard. Should family reunion only be the preserve of the rich? The total cost of sponsoring parents to Australia is now $17,060 plus airfares. For middle and low income Australians the cost is now simply prohibitive.

These regulations must be seen in the context of the overall erosion of the family reunion category. A total of 8,890 parent visas were issued in 1995-96. This has been whittled down now to a mere 2,500 parent visas. Meanwhile, the queue has grown to 19,600 parent applicants who have applied to join their children here. Parents have been particularly hard hit by the capping and queuing practice of the federal government. The capping of parent visas has created indefinite waiting periods for large numbers of parents. Many may well die waiting.

Yet there is no quota on the number of applicants who may be granted visas in the new category. The wealthy will be able to avoid the lengthy delays caused by capping of parent visas. I remind the Senate that there are 19,600 parents waiting in the queue. We should also bear in mind that those here as refugee or humanitarian entrants cannot visit their home of origin. They may never see their parents again.

These new regulations are in response to the perceived direct costs associated with family reunion migration, particularly for parents aged over 45. However, the cost analysis does not take into account indirect economic benefits and social benefits that flow to Australia through family reunion migration. Economic formulations do not take into account benefits such as child care, physical and emotional support and cultural education; these are not of zero value.

I share the view of the South Brisbane Immigration and Community Legal Service: `The need to have a fair immigration system which does not discriminate harshly against the poor, nor destroy family is fundamental to a just society.' These regulations lay our immigration law open to a charge of being a law for the rich which discriminates against the poor and underprivileged.

The minister has said he will cut the quota for parent reunions by 50 per cent to just 500 a year if this disallowance succeeds. This would result in waiting times of up to 40 years for parents already in the queue. I do not believe we should make decisions in this place based on these sorts of threats. I acknowledge that the minister, whom I respect and who has a feel for this, is under considerable constraints. I acknowledge he has taken some steps to lessen some of the harsh effects of these regulations, for example, allowing parents with children to apply onshore. However, this does not go to the heart of the problem with these regulations, that is, that the majority of applicants are discriminated against because of their lack of financial means.

I have tried hard to find a way through all this. I have not been unmoved by calls from those who believe this new visa category may be the only chance they have to bring their parents out. But we need to address the very real needs of those languishing in the queues. Until these needs are addressed, I can do nothing other than support the disallowance motion.

talk.start.para: —I rise to thank honourable senators for their contributions and to say that if we defer a motion to the last day it does put a bit of pressure on. Maybe it is a lesson for all of us that we should try to debate such a motion the day before the last day so we are not in this situation.

speech.para: I would like to reply to what Senator Harradine said. I would not always want to speak on behalf of everyone in this chamber, but I think I could speak on behalf of everyone in this chamber today and say: if we had our druthers, if it were an ideal world, we would want every single person who had migrated to Australia to be able to be reunited with their parents and bring them here. That is not possible.

One of the reasons it is not possible is that it would distort our population profile. The other reason is that it would place a very large burden on our social security system. Despite the rule that older people who migrate here must live here for 10 years before they can receive the pension, an inordinate number of people of working age who come in the aged parent visa category end up on unemployment benefits, and many end up on special benefits, because the families fail to meet their obligations. It is not all families. Many families who bring their older relatives here do the right thing and care for them.

But, as a government, we have to make judgments about the extent to which people should be expected to provide for older relatives who migrate here; relatives who have not made a contribution in Australia or who come from countries that do not have reciprocal pension arrangements with Australia. These are judgments that have to be made. We could not accept the number of people who are applying in the parent category and at the rate at which they are applying.

When the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Ruddock, went around last year consulting on immigration issues, one of the issues that was raised by a number of the groups was: `Couldn't we have a category for people who have made a commitment to care for their parents and to be financially responsible for them?' That came out of those community consultations, and some of the people who were asking for that were from some of the welfare organisations. So the minister decided to develop regulations that would accommodate that request.

In my new role as parliamentary secretary, I was with the minister in his consultations right around Australia, and people were positive about that development. We went to every capital city, and there was not any criticism made. We had public meetings, we met with peak bodies, and not one person was critical of those regulations. In fact, they thanked the minister for introducing them.

I was at a meeting here in Parliament House with a number of organisations, and one of the groups went over the same thing. They said they wanted a regulation that contained a category where the sponsoring family took responsibility. The minister said, `We have that, but it is at risk at the moment because we have a motion in the Senate to disallow the regulation.' I have to tell you that those people were nothing short of horrified.

We have heard that the parents of people who are wealthy or have more income than others will be able to jump the queue ahead of others. Let me put the argument the other way. Senator Harradine and others might disagree that there has to be a cap, but I think the Australian public has reached the point of saying, `We need a cap because we cannot support an inordinate number of people.' If we have a cap and we do not have these regulations, everybody will be in the queue. Therefore, those who could afford to be included in the category that is covered in these regulations would preclude those who cannot afford to be there. So you would preclude people who cannot afford to come. That is the thing that honourable senators have to think about.

I think you will find that the community is quite concerned. I can say from my personal experience of nearly all of those consultations with the minister right around Australia, including rural Australia, there was not one concern expressed. Any comments that were made about these regulations were positive.
I am very sad tonight. My mother migrated to America when I was about 21 years old—
Senator Carr interjecting—

talk.start.para: —Thank you, Senator Carr. That was an unnecessary interjection. I did not ever expect that I would have a right to be reunited with her—as her last relative in Australia—in America. I know that sometimes these decisions are made when you are younger, and you do not realise you are going to get older. It is difficult, and I understand the difficulties people face when they have a relative living in another country. But it is not possible for us to allow everyone who applies to come. We were hoping to make it easier for some and to ensure that we could have as many as possible. I regret that the Senate has made this decision tonight. I hope, if the minister decides to reintroduce this regulation—he may not—that you will consider it again.

speech.para: Again, I express my regret. I express my regret to those people who are in the queue. I have forgotten how many have applied and voted with their feet to transfer across categories—it is something like 2,800 people. I say to those 2,800 people tonight: I am very sorry that you will have to go back into the queue and you will not have the opportunity of having your parents here as soon as you thought. That is my regret tonight.

talk.start.para: —I am quite sorry that this is the standard of the government's debate. I am afraid that we will get to the situation where immigration will go to the highest bidder. Perhaps this would be a good way of raising more revenue!

speech.para: I am absolutely disgusted, when we see evidence again and again in this chamber of groups that have been gagged or de-funded for speaking out—migration groups that have lost their funding, who do not exist or cannot exist as lobbyists anymore—that the government can come in here and say, `As those who don't speak to us or criticise us when we speak to them, it means there is no dissent.' They come to groups like us. They come to groups like the Democrats. They may come to groups like the Labor Party or Senator Harradine because they know that, if they go to the government, the government will say, `We don't pay you to criticise us.'

How dare you come in and suggest that, if people have not expressed their concern or criticised government to your face, that is a sign there is no discontent. It is a sign that your policies of gagging dissent have been very, very effective. Do not come into this chamber and say that, if people do not say to your face that they have concerns about your programs, it means there is no problem. There are problems in your programs. A strong government is one which is prepared to listen to those issues and not gag those people systematically for speaking out.

This is unfortunate. There are a lot of emotions here, but we should not be a country which sells off places of immigration to the highest bidder, and this is what it is getting to. It is not fair, it is not right, and therefore I will be supporting the disallowance.

talk.start.para: —in reply—There are a couple of matters I need to respond to. I note the parliamentary secretary's comment that the government is hoping to have as many people as possible. I hope that that is followed through by the minister and that he does not follow through on his unnecessary threat to severely restrict the amount of people overall that are able to get in here. If that does happen, then clearly there will be a lot more people negatively affected than the ones that the parliamentary secretary has expressed concerns about.

speech.para: It is a shame we did not have time to fully debate the issues, because they are important and complex. The reason why it was continually deferred was not that I was not ready to deal with it but that other senators indicated they were not ready to deal with it, so I had to keep deferring it. It is important that the parliament's responsibility to make a judgment on this matter has been fulfilled. I do thank other senators for their support for the motion.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
